He never mentioned an argument against whether or not animals actually have the capability to suffer. Suffering is an experience that can only be present in a conscious mind. There are many unknowns around what make up a conscious perceiver/mind. We hypothesize that at least it's the capability of metacognition, Language and memory. There are no other animals on this planet that are capable of all of these things in the same way a human being is. Suffering requires a conscious perceiver to be defined as suffering, not a functional reaction to a given input in the brain of an animal. For example, When you have surgery and the doctor cuts you open while you're unconscious, the pain neurons and receptors are still firing in the same functional way they do while you're conscious and in the same way an animal's would. However, because you're unconscious, you aren't suffering. Therefor, animals incapable of having a conscious are also incapable of having experience of any kind at all... They are simply functional being that give behavioral outputs to specific inputs, much like a programmed computer.

I think the moral discussion here is all based on assumptions. The utilitarian framework is one that is based on an axiomatic position, and that is: what is harmful is that which is bad. I fail to see that as an established fact.
Since they’re working from assumptions one can also work from assumption and circumvent the problem of “I want to do whatever I want,” by saying that that which is desired is that which is good. And that can pretty much justify why I would eat a cow but not a cat, because I simply want. Of course, all these starting points are subjective, but given these facts, one can make claims within the frameworks that arise from those starting points.
I, of course, don’t follow that assumption.
And of course within the utilitarian framework, the statement of not eating animals is not entirely consistent. The utilitarian framework deals with pain and pleasure. And we can also add the principle of the greatest good for the
greatest number of people. That is a sound concept until you ask: are a hundred extremely happy people better than a billion almost miserable people? And after all, when we consume pleasure at the expense of the pain of animals, then we have maximized our pleasure. So then my question to you, the reader, is: is a great amount of pleasure okay if it is accompanied by a great amount of pain? And is it better or worse than substantially less pleasure accompanied by substantially less pain? Keep in mind that the utilitarian framework says that pleasure=good and pain=bad. Essentially what we're saying is: great evil and great good, small good and small evil

Yes, the vegetarian side of the argument is not difficult to defend, but it isn't completely infallible. There are many examples of how human consumption of animals has had a morally positive impact in some form. First, let's talk about livestock. Animals such as cows and sheep are domesticated and would not likely survive (and definitely not survive at their current numbers) without human protection. These animals only are protected by humans because of their use to us, they are able to pass their genes onto their offspring without worry about their survival, which is an affordance most wild animals do not have. In this, human cultivation of livestock could be considered a mutually beneficial contract so long as the animals are treated humanly throughout their existence. What I am implying here is that while the consumption of animal products is not necessarily wrong, our current methods of mass-producing them are inexcusable. The second example I would like to bring up is animals such as deer, where humans have removed all of their natural predators and our hunting of them only serves to maintain balance in an ecosystem that we have a duty to maintain since we were the ones who sent it into imbalance into the first place.
Those are my two main arguments, I would love to hear any issues with them since I haven't found a good place to voice them and so they are likely somewhat flawed.

I experienced today what you described towards the end of this video. A family member was debating for hours with me about how voting for a particular candidate was a slippery slope towards giving too much power to one side of the political spectrum. I found myself perfectly justified in all my compact reasons, but this family member brought up so many countless lengthy claims that were fallacies that didn’t feel like I could persistently argue with them about the complexity of each each issue at without seeming close-minded myself. Before I could formulate any response to deconstruct what was clearly a skip in rationality, another flawed point would be made. It would help if I was well-versed in identifying fallacies by name when confronted with something that should be immediately refuted before being expounded upon.
All in all, the conversation was over before it really began for a plethora of reasons. I can’t help but wonder now if there are some people you just can’t have a productive, rational discussion with about real life issues. I’m also just about fed up with the bureaucracy and triviality of the social contract world I live in. Sometimes I just want to go to an island with a handful of people who I can live harmoniously with and just live happily.
This begs the question though, are we better off focusing on our own immediate environments and trying to fix that? Because trying to establish a universal philosophy that applies not just to the nation but to every human individual and group just seems impossible. Yet we have a civic duty to vote, and if we don’t vote then are we morally to blame when bad things happen or do we just relinquish our right to decry any such outcomes?

While there are really great arguments made by anti-meat philosophers, I have to disagree with the claim that an animal's life is just as valuable as a human's.

Animals come in two varieties: solitary and social. These categories represent two very different survival strategies. Neither is necessarily superior to the other, but each comes with its own pluses and minuses.

The survival strategy for socialized species can vary wildly, but the part that remains the same from species to species is this: I do things for you that benefit your survival and/or well-being but that does not benefit my own survival and/or well-being. If enough individuals in our social group do this, then everyone in the group experiences a very large increase in survival and/or well-being even if the contribution of each individual is relatively small.

Humans are a social species, and like most species that use socialization as a survival strategy, our primary survival strategy is each other.

Even the most seemingly-useless humans in any given society can profoundly affect your survival chances.

Non-sentient animals simply do not impact my well-being and survival chances as much as other humans do. Maybe someday we will encounter other sentient species and they will become part of our society and be just as valuable to human survival and well-being as other humans, but for now, it's just humans at the top of that particular list.

Does this necessarily mean that eating meat is justified? Not necessarily. Most of us eat meat out of habit (myself included), and it takes far more farmland to produce meat than veggies/grains, so we're at the point where switching all of humanity away from meat could save a lot of human lives.

But I still insist that the life of a human is more important to me than the life of, say, a cow, and I make no apologies for that view.

Further, cows are a particular case. The wild version of cattle went extinct a long time ago. If humans didn't have a fondness for eating the meat of domesticated cattle, their species would have been entirely extinct a long time ago.

I grant that most farm animals live under impossibly cruel conditions, but they also exist in far larger numbers than they would if humans didn't eat meat. I'm not sure how many more or fewer species would be extinct if humans didn't eat meat. I really don't.
So if we hypothetically were able to give animals medicines or immediately destroy their nervous systems, it would be okay because they would not suffer any pain.

Hank did a great job presenting sound and reasonable argument. I’ll try to engage with reason. In a way, the methodology of pro-vegan does not escape speciesism, just engages it in a broader sense, “animalism” if you will. As far as I can see, being pro-vegan ONLY because of anti-speciesism is “FEELING like animales deserve more than vegetables”, which is not Reason. Although, I do want to point out there are many who is pro-vegan for other reasons like health benefits and I have total respect for them. I don’t even hold feeling as completely invalid argument in this case, as the suffering itself is feeling-based. I only try to offer my point of view from a purely reasoned perspective as a potential interlocutor. Very impressive educational series indeed!

It is not that we utilize animal products that creates a true moral dilemma. It is how we treat them while they live. Animals eat animals. Insects eat insects. Fish eat fish. Birds eat birds. But only humans raise animals for the purpose of killing and utilizing them and how they have to live while waiting for their ultimate demise and use is the real dilemma.

Everything dies. It is how animals live that is the moral interest, in my opinion. As soon as we can create GMO strains of steakfruit and bacon bushes, the use of animals as food can be eliminated. That still leaves us with the question of what to do about all the animals that don’t observe our morality and ethics and that is 100% of non human animals. How do you enforce animal rights? A right must be enforced and how we stop wolves, lions, bears and preying mantises (among others) from eating weaker animals alive is going to be a challenge.

Perhaps the best argument for animal utilization is that we are not above nature but a product of it, instead. We have as much right to eat animals as every other animal has and only the fact that we are so successful in life that we have time to agonize over such moral dilemmas separates us from the rest of the animals on this planet.

There are many tricky philosophical problems in life and this is one of the hardest to get our heads around because if the highly emotional nature of it, which is a direct result of our highly developed sense of empathy. Empathy was crucial to human development and organization. It empowers us but every strength comes with a weakness and the weakness is that we are disturbed by the very nature of life (and death).

This is exactly the logic that lead me to veganism. I do agree that one day our ancestors will be horrified with the ways we currently exploit animals. I'm so proud of everyone who has defied social norms and realized that veganism is the only morally consistent way forward!

If I believed I could be as healthy being vegan or vegetarian as eating meat, I would stop eating meat altogether.  However, there's substantial evidence to the contrary.  While it might be possible to be reasonably healthy being long-term vegan (with careful supplementation), it's a far harder claim to make that eating a very healthy vegan diet is as healthy as a very healthy omnivore diet.  Adding seafood to the mix changes that considerably, but seafood has its own health and ethical issues to navigate, namely, toxins, heavy metals and sustainability.

If you're having a hard time imagining how eating meat could really increase the amount of animals that are killed, consider this analogy. When you take a drink out of a vending machine, a new drink slides into place behind it, and another drink slides into place behind that one and on an on in a chain back to the back of the vending machine. Eventually an employee is going to have to put more drinks into the back of the vending machine to replace them. Similarly, Eating meat involves buying meat from a butcher, and when somebody buys meat from a butcher, the butcher will have to replace it with more meat from the slaughterhouse, and when meat is bought from a slaughterhouse, that meat will have to be replaced by a cow farm.
Also, I sometimes like to think of it like this. In a world where everybody ate beef, farmers would raise a lot of cows. In a world where everybody were vegetarian, farmers wouldn't raise cows (or maybe they would just raise them for leather or something? anyway, it would be a lot fewer cows), because of the laws of supply and demand. Now imagine a sliding scale between those two worlds. As you change the number of vegetarians, you change the number of cows being killed. So one person's decision to become vegetarian makes a difference in this sense. But honestly Hank making this video may have made more of a difference than me being vegetarian for the rest of my life.

This brief philosophical course about considering the rights of non-human animals is NOT about whether you are vegan or an omnivore. This is primarily about how we can draw the line of what should be considered right and wrong on who should be allowed to suffer and why for our own benefit.

We (at this moment) as a species have dominated every other. We have made our own communities so expansive that if any other species come into contact with our own, they may as well be considered dead because of how bad we are as people.

And Vegans should stop praising this video as if it was about them. It is obvious to me how vegans love to put themselves on a pedestal because they do not consume meat, however, some of them still lack the capacity to empathize with other beings (human and non-human). Consider the fact that not consuming meat does not mean that chickens and cows will stop suffering, because there will always be others who will still do it.

Any way if your ancestors never consumed another animal, then we would not be here today. Unfortunately, the human species has done a lot of damage to itself and others to reach the top. But it is up to us to see if we are capable of educating ourselves for the good of not our species but for the good of all species. We should consider ourselves the "protectors" of our dominated world, and seek to help others. We already help those species that are closest to us and that's a good starting point.

Perhaps we should start including a mandatory course as part of our science/environmental efforts to help understand other species and how to best interact with them.

So I've probably watched 10 or so of your videos now and this is the first time I have to say... I don't know.

My first hurdle is that I believe plants are alive and have spirits just as dog and cats and I don't know to what extent they feel pain (they can't express it as near as I can tell, but that doesn't mean they can't experience it).

I could possibly make an argument about agency (bare with me, I'm thinking this up as I type). I see no evidence that plants can make any choices. In this sense they are agents to act but are acted upon. However, I have been taught that making decisions is necessary but not sufficient for agency.

To simplify, agency is the ability to choose between right and wrong. To make such a choice we must have both knowledge and comprehension of right and wrong. So can a dog sin?... can it somehow choose not to fulfill the measure of its creation? What about a beansprout? Once again, I don't know, and if there is a plan of salvation for animals, I don't know what it is.

Nobody on Earth can reasonably make the argument that is made in this video. The argument of need is very likely to be legitimate for very many people. Nutrition and human genetic diversity are deeply complicated, and we don't yet know exactly how omitting an entire category of food (animals) would actually effect the entire human population. Veganism is an untested hypothesis with virtually no long term outcome data, and it decides to effectively roll the dice with its assumption that abandoning animal foods is a good idea on a global scale. There is no defensible reason to believe that this isn't potentially dangerous, based on the preponderance of data.

There is more to animal foods than B12, and there is certainly more to animal foods than what we currently understand. In staunchly adopting veganism, you close the door to both known and unknown benefits of animal foods. An omnivorous diet need not close either of these doors, or the doors to known and unknown benefits of plant foods either. I know enough of about human nutritional science to understand that there is currently no way for most of us outrun the need to eat well, and unfortunately meat is still an inescapable part of eating well for many, many people.

So I've been thinking about pro-meat-eating arguments and would be interested to hear people's thoughts.

In terms of species differences, I think intelligence is morally relevant because humans have a heightened ability to plan for the future. For example, I might work very hard at university so that I get a good job and can support my family, therefore killing me would shorten my life before I get the opportunity to enjoy the benefits of my preparation for later life. It would also have an impact on society in that others have invested a lot in training me up, but would not then benefit from my service and I would not be able to educate others.

Secondly, specism might make sense because the logic behind morals seems to be that I can do something nice for you and you can do something nice for me back. Or the converse; I won't steal your stuff so you don't steal mine and we'll get along and mutually benefit from our relationship. Therefore our society has developed a moral system for humans that makes sense, but the moral boundary lies at animals because they can't do anything for us (other than providing us with meat). Slaves do not fall outside this boundary because they can help us and contribute to society in every way a white person can.

A combination of two significant factors contribute to my declaration of eating pets as unethical. One factor is a relational factor and the other are social factors. Social factors contributing to the unethical idea of eating pets are completely reinforced by social convention. Although it is not illegal to eat the meat from our pets, conventions within our society would suggest it to be morally wrong. In Canada, cats and dogs are the most commonly kept animals as pets. Approximately thirty five percent of Canadian households in 2011 own a dog and nearly thirty eight percent of households own a cat (Canadian Veterinary Medical Association, 2011). Relationships formed with these common pets lay the framework of social norms on how humans treat every pet regardless of species. Dogs have been thought to be domesticated for nearly 32,000 years (PHYS, 2017) and cats 10,000 years (TheNest, 2017). Given this information we can see how societal factors regarding treatment of pets and the very definition of what a pet is, have been developed over the last 32,000 years. For instance, societal convention has lead us to the idea that it is commonplace to consider our pets a member of our family and not just an animal. Once accepted into the family unit, one considers the animals interests to be equal to those of which the other family members have. Peter Singer, an Australian moral philosopher and prominent voice in animal rights, best illustrates animal interest equality in a line from his book Animal Liberation (1975) saying “The basic principle of equality does not require equal or identical treatment; it requires equal consideration”. Surely one does not treat their loved ones the same as a cat or dog. We do not command our kids and wives to use the backyard as a bathroom, we cannot command our siblings to fetch or roll over but, the consideration we have for the interests are equal. One feeds and houses their pet as a parent would their child, in most cases of medical distress our pets are rushed to the doctor as we would for a human loved one. Considering these points, it would be preposterous to eat a member of the family thus giving a clear concrete answer to the question: under which circumstances, if any, is it wrong to eat animals? Our pets.

I think it has to deal with emotional attachment. We have no personal feelings to a random cow or pig that we end up eating for nutrition and taste, but eating a treasured family pet is horrifying because of the emotional attachment we have to said pet. The same applies to rabbits in testing labs— we use the products tested on them so we feel shame and guilt because of the emotional attachment we have to the animal. It would explain why we continue to eat meat despite being able to live with out it, since we feel no emotional compulsion to stop, but it would also explain why we feel grief when certain animals die and why we don’t when others pass as well. The same goes for humans. We hear about a random person dying across the ocean- so what? We don’t know them, we never have and never will, why should their death impact us? I know that Hank is not a vegan and me neither! I see the moral between human and other species in a contractarianism manner. With domesticated animal the contracts are clear: human provide food, shelter and healthcare, animals provide either their substances (meat, leather, egg, etc) or their service. With farm animals, the contract is a simple exchange, humans raise them, breed them then kill them and take their stuff as paybacks. It might seem like an 'unfair' contract but it is the currently the contract. That also means that it is currently the right thing to do, although a shift in the future can happen. That shift will be decided by the entire society as a whole: so I don't think a wholesale elimination of the killings will happen soon.

But with work and companion animals there are extra elements. For example with cats and dogs, human needed them to be more sociable and less murderous so that they can be kept roaming in our proximity as guards and companions; they complied and evolved to creatures that tend to bond well with human. This is why I oppose the killing and eating of work and companion animals such as cats, dogs, horses and others because socialisation and bonding are part of the contract, thus killing them becomes much more morally questionable. This immorality is agreed upon by a lot of people, even if they don't necessarily think in similar terms.

As for wild animals, the contract we have with them is less obvious; but I believe the recently established contract is just not to disturb them too much, as we have learnt that a decreased biodiversity sucks. Hence, is why I am ok with eating some animals but not the others.

The issue of eating meat is one I've gone back and fourth with for awhile, and I think my answer fundamentally comes down to it's rational and as a rational person I shouldn't do it but I do anyway therefore it is a contradiction that proves I am lacking when held to my own moral standards.  For me the arguments go a little like this: 1. I consider good an evil to be abstract constructs without and that there is no universal right or wrong.  2.  Lacking an innate universal morality I instead choose to create my own personal code of morality by which to live my life and must therefore base this code of morality on what I perceive to be reason based on the information I have on hand. 3. Based on available data that I perceive to be true I have no rational justification for valuing one life over another, (and even valuing animals over plant life or bacteria is as much of an irrational justification as animal speciesism) yet I am constantly making the choice to kill in favor of making my life better and even my own antibodies are doing so at all times without my conscious knowledge. 4. I must ultimately accept that I like all life kind am part of a ongoing struggle where in life consumes life.  5.  I by my own moral standards am obligated to try to reduce the cruelty (as I see it) in the universe when and where I am able, yet I must all accept that I will never be fully capable of doing so.

This video fails to mention Carl Cohen's primary argument regarding why animals cannot have rights...

Dr. Cohen's actual argument is: "The maintenance of rights depends on an understanding of the universe as a morally fraught system. Those that are incapable of the conception of morality derive their moral stature from those who do. Therefore, those that do not understand morality are not autonomous in the frame of morality, and cannot maintain rights. Only members of a species with the autonomous capacity to comprehend and maintain rights can exist inside the framework of "rights." Non-human animal species do not have that capacity. Therefore, members of non-human animal species do not have rights. Though they have many very serious privileges which humans bestow upon them; but humans are not accountable to those animals for providing those privileges - humans are instead accountable to other humans for providing non-human animals with the agreed-upon privileges, and this is further evidence that the privileges that animals have cannot be described as rights. Though, of course, there exists an important moral necessity to treat animals in a manner that befits the moral human world, and there are understandable differences in opinion on what such privileges should be."

If you wanted to summarize that argument for children, I'd endorse, "Non-human animals cannot understand the concept of rights, so any rights we give them would be "given rights" and "given rights" are commonly understood to be called, "priviliges" instead of "rights."

Happy thinking, y'all!

I am for the humane treatment of animals who are being raised for food, that should be a given, even though in our world it is not. That being said, to say that eating meat is morally wrong is ludicrous. In nature animals all up and down the food chain eat meat, and people, whether we all realize it or not, are part of nature. Comparing domestication of animals to human slavery is not accurate because it willfully ignores the fact that humans are the only sentient beings on the planet. As long as living conditions for domesticated animals are humane, then their life will be no worse than the life they would have in the wild and depending on the species it could be longer and less stressful. Animals have the right to humane treatment, in that causing them undue suffering in the name of profit is morally wrong, but to say that they need the same rights and protections as a sentient being is willful ignorance of reality.

With exceptions such as Dolphins or gorillas, non-human animals are typically not conscious. This justification says that the idea of the need to survive comes with consciousness. You don't eat a conscious being. But you need to eat, and a chicken is no more conscious than a corn plant. However, additionally the discrimination of which non-conscious animals we will eat revolves around specific societies. In Ecuador, they eat Guinea pigs like we in the US eat chickens. The difference, is that we keep Guinea pigs as pets. Pets, for example cats, are considered by the society to be conscious. Thus, we do not eat pets because they are conscious beings. In my opinion, the need to survive for humans or other conscious beings outways the need to survive for nonconcious beings. Thus, what we eat is decided by the society we live in and the morals we subscribe to.

I have thought alot about the question of animal treatment, and if it's right to keep animals as livestock, pets, in zoos etc. In nature, animals are adapted to their environments. The environment shapes the species, the different factors affects it in different ways. A domesticated animal is an animal that has evolved to what it is today not by the different "natural factors", but by humans factors, the "rules" of evolution and adaption still applies, it's just that we choose who survives, breeds etc and so the species is adapted to us, "survival of the fittest". A sheep or a dog isn't a wild animal, they couldn't really survive in the wild, they're adapted to humans, a mutual beneficial "agreeement". What's the difference between dying in nature because of disease, predators or malnutrition, or dying at the butchery? An animal isn't afraid of death, they don't have the abstract notion of death. A sheep, or a chicken "wants"/instinctually seeks food, shelter, companion. A chicken in a huge chicken coop has food, water, shelter and companionship with other chickens, they have notion about death, they don't care if we choose when they die, how is that different from the different factors of nature "choosing" when they die, the species that is chicken exists because we want it to, should we stop raising chickens? Then they wouldn't exist, is that "fair". Now, the argument about pain is of course a legit one. Is it worth existing if you're in pain? No one is advocating for cruel treatment of animals just for the sake of it, putting chickens in cages so small they can't move etc, but animals feel pain/get hurt in nature too, can the benefits outweigh the disadvantages?. This is an economical decision and not about the principles of "using" animals in general. We should of course treat livestock and domesticated animals better if possible. I eat meat, i see no reason why not, I keep dogs as pets. We humans have a mutual beneficial relationships with the domesticated animals

When it comes to wild animals, zoos and hunting etc. Zoos often does not treat animals as good as they should, but still, what is most important, to be alive, or to have it as good as possible? A lion wants a huge area to roam free, well, there isn't enough nature left for that many lions, live in a zoo or don't live at all, what would you choose?. Secondly a zoo educates and show people the fantastic wildlife we have on earth, increasing awareness about the problems facing the species and nature in general, this is of course not saying that zoos couldnt improve the way they treat animals, trying to make their environments as natural as possible, but that zoos in general are not a bad thing. Rather a life in a cage that no life at all.
Hunting is multifaceted. We have hunted animals to extinction. In industrialised countries the top predators are often extinct or the population so small they're irrelevant. Animals like for example deer or moose no longer has any natural enemies and the hunting is often necessary to keep the ecosystem in balance. When it comes to trophy hunting like elephants and lions this of course can be viewed as a bad thing, the species are endangered or worse, but often this kind of trophy hunting provides important funding and awareness necessary to preserving a species as a whole, in contrast to the often much more harmfull poaching

I would personally have large difficulties directly hurting an animal (or a person for that matter), but I still eat meat, I still enjoy zoos and I'm not against the idea of hunting, even though I myself would probably not enjoy it.

A simple way around veganism/vegetarianism problem is adopting a different ethical standard than you mentioned in this video, it's not as accepted but there is something called emotivism.  Basically the school of though goes as follows:  Moral claims are not rational, reasonable claims.  There is no way to completely satisfy any kind of objective true morality (which this is an extension of existentialism and meaning).  That doesn't mean anarchy and amoralism, but moral claims are relative to who is expressing them.  Emotivism is basically saying that moral claims are emotions/reactions to events (or future events that would happen).  This is not rational, but you can still have a discussion about your emotions about something, it's reasonable irrational thoughts. Nature is amoral; it does not concern itself with delivering desirable treatment. Why, then, should humans?

1. We tend to assume that our species is divorced from nature - that we somehow live in a separate dimension. This observation is evident in the way we arbitrarily distinguish the natural from the unnatural. The truth is everything we act upon is natural - yes, even industrial waste is natural by definition. We are just another animal, as implied in the title of this crash course. We could apply ecological analyses to human behavior as we do to every other species'.

2. A distinguishing factor between our species and other sentient species is the degree of our cognition. Most of us can feel pain at a higher plane than all other animals because we are more aware of that pain, thus adding a layer of psychological and emotional torment that other species simply aren't equipped to process. This difference, however, is of degree, not kind.

3. We rarely meddle in the moral affairs of other species. We could subjugate all carnivores and feed them only unsentient products of nature. Surely those carnivores could survive on a vegetarian diet, or at least a diet consisting of flesh derived without inflicting pain to that flesh's owner (such as byvalves, which possess no central nervous system). Doing this would prevent other species, like lions, from engaging in the same seemingly barbaric and unnecessary diets most of us still practice.

4. Perhaps you believe that morality should not be normative, which means that one is justified in calling out and refraining from participating in the meat industry without imposing a moral requirement upon others. This would explain your inadvertent decision not to impose a moral diet upon other species and upon other human beings. But what good is morality if it is not normative? Morality dictates ethics, which deals with "what one ought do." If you take the ought out of ethics, you have "what one does." Therefore, saying that decisions are morally restricted to individuals pragmatically boils down to the statement that individuals chose what individuals chose, which is a meaningless tutelage. Thus, a non-normative morality is an admittance of universal (yes, applicable even to humans) amorality, meaning that no one has a moral duty to others. Such a conclusion certainly is congruent with our observations of nature acting upon its species, other species acting upon other species, and, (usually) with the exception of humans, species acting upon their own.

Based primarily on these four ideas, I propose that if one is to be philosophically consistent in adjusting his or her lifestyle to favor a moral diet, he or she must either accept moral anti-realism (which leaves no grounds with which to require others to act in a way you deem appropriate) or impose your moral diet upon all species.

How does my proposition follow from the above ideas? Here is my explanation: if we are as natural as nature's other species, then appealing to our membership in the human species is not a morally relevant factor that warrants our adherence to moral standards while simultaneously failing to apply those standards to other species. In other words, we need a reason to have special moral standards, and being of a certain species is not sufficient justification. Moreover, the main factor that distinguishes other species from us is the degree of cognition. Only a difference of kind (and not of degree) could justify our adherence to a separate moral standard. Therefore, from the first two ideas I concluded that whatever moral standard we adhere to must not be hypocritically applied exclusively to humans; if living on a diet without inflicting pain on other beings is morally preferable, then that moral standard applies to all species. The third idea was simply to expose that we currently don't apply this moral standard to other species. The only way this neglect could be justified is if we accept that our standards in choosing an ethical diet are not binding, which as shown in idea #4, would lead to an overall pragmatic equivalent of amorality. Thus, the only escape from the amorality that nature displays is to apply these moral standards to all species to prevent them from engaging in an immoral diet (if you do indeed believe there is such a thing).

Of course, if you don't accept my ideas, then my proposition won't follow. But if you do, the only other way to escape my proposition is if some other ideal holds priority over the ideals that could lead one to repudiate the meat diet.

In fact, cellulose from plant based meals cannot be digested by our human bodies.. As much as I acknowledge that a huge percentage of the vegan community is sincerely empathetic, kind and truly concerned with animal well being, the vegan argument in my opinion is driven by emotions, and stems from an inherent desire to be righteous and to fulfill a purpose, than it is driven by an objective outlook and understanding of the human physiology and what it's supposed to actually do and feed on. We are simply being selective about behaviours that we believe we exhibit as a consequence of our evolution. So it's morally right to eat meat if I can justify it? Okay: The implied premise that humans are not animals is false.

If humans are not animals, then the possibility that we are entitled to being speciesist and should do whatever we please, including eating them with no regards to moral, is valid.

If humans are animals, and it's our moral obligation to not cause harm to animals, then we are also morally obligated to prevent any other animal from causing harm to any other animals because animals shouldn't cause other animals harm.
But if you agree animals can cause harm on other animals, then we can too, and I can eat them. Otherwise you'd be speciesist in favor of other animals.

That being said, If you think we shouldn't eat animals, then you either think humans are not animals, which is false, or you're a speciesist against humans.

Is killing and/or harming animals morally right?

To me, you would need to define what to feel pain means. Where does the limits for "pain feeling" go? Can a stone feel pain? Can a tree feel pain? Can an ant or a fish? A tree can, just like most animals, react to negative stimuli by for example increasing the synthesis of proteins meant to protect it from the harm (insect munching on it). A fish will try to escape or fight. A human will scream, cry, try to escape from the pain etc.

Should we base the sensation of pain on humans? If an animal (including humans) is peacefully (without inducing fear) killed under anaestetics and said animal does not know about the concept of death, could that be classified as a neutral action?

Based on my thoughts around this, I think we should base the rights of animals on their ability to percieve the world, not on their ability to sense pain. We can make sensors to detect mechanical stimuli just as well as DNA can, but feeling does not equal complex perception. I think it is a gradient, based on cognitive function.

All this talk of pain/suffering as the primary separation between organisms which can and cannot be harmed makes me immensely curious exactly what the definition of pain being used here is.  Which precise evolutionary adaptation upon the tree of life marks the line between "signaling" and "pain"?  Every organism, from humans to dogs jellyfish to insects to plants to fungi to yeast to bacteria has some capacity to signal when a problem arises in normal growth and development and prompt the organism to alter its inner workings and/or behavior as a result.  At precisely what point does rudimentary signaling become morally distinguishable from what we as humans experience as pain/suffering?  No matter how you slice it, placing a line in the sand appears to me to be casting judgement on the complexity of the organism's responsiveness, or "intelligence".

I really only continue to consume animal products because I medically have to. I can't properly digest most grains, nuts and legumes, as well as fruits and vegetables in large amounts. something most people can do, which means that if I were to go completely vegan, or even vegetarian, I wouldn't be able to get all of the vitamins and protein that I need. but I still feel shame for having this medical need and try to cut as many corners as I can to avoid hurting animals. for example, I limit how often I eat meat to once per 2-3 days and refuse to eat animals that are immature in age (no lamb/veal) or have intellect equivalent to a human child or higher (no pigs). I also try to avoid the use of animal products if I can in baked goods, homemade or store-bought. So yes, in the particular scenario of medical necessity, it is okay for humans to kill and eat other sentient beings. But only for the purpose of food, and we should not kill (or purchase) more than we are going to eat simply because an animal suffered so you could eat that.

Animals do not have 'rights' in the natural sense and neither do humans. Humans have the capacity to posit rights in the form of contract, which we share exclusive and utterly with other humans alone. Animals and yes, even marginal humans like infants and the mentally disabled, are only objects of morality, not subjects or participants.

Most of the animal rights arguments are contradictory for the same reasons they point out in their opponents. For instance, if suffering were the threshold of having moral status or consideration then the "marginal human" argument just gets flipped back onto them.
Pain is not the same thing as suffering. Pain is a biochemical response, suffering is a psychological response. They correlate very often but they aren't identical.
That being said, infants and the severely mentally handicapped are incapable of experiencing proper suffering and so the animal rights proponents who use the "suffering qualification" can't explain why it isn't permissible to kill or abuse infants or the disabled.

I think a key thing many people forget is that there can be such a thing as balance. We provide for the animals we eat (for the most part) and spend heavily on them; therefore we should be able to eat them. However, we lose that balance when we subject them to terrible conditions in the name of cost-effectiveness, efficiency, etc. This would apply to the dogs or cats as well, we provided for them and are therefore able to dictate whether or not we eat them, but those that mistreat them should not receive that choice. While not explicit, I think many arguments wander dangerously close to the "either-or" fallacy, on both sides. In the end, however, I don't believe arguments can hold water and convince people to change without some compromise.

First he brings up intelligence but compares humans with the lowest intelligence to animals that exceed them in intelligence. I think if someone is a Speciesist, it's might not be because they think all humans are more intelligent than non-human animals. Rather that most humans are, therefore humans, as a species, are superior. Thus, even the humans with lower intelligence are superior, simply because they belong to the superior species. So in that way, a Speciesist wouldn't need to believe that it's right to treat members of our species differently because of a lack of intelligence, but might still think so when it comes to non-human animals.

Then he brings up Cohen's proud speciesism and "might makes right". He says you wouldn't be okay with it if you weren't a member of the privileged species and then brings up slavery. But slavery was so egregious precisely because those enslaved weren't a different species. Whereas, in this case, we are dealing with different species, and if you think nature consists of a fight between species to reach and remain at the top, it would be consistent to oppose slavery of humans and not oppose slavery of non-human animals. Though, obviously, the principle of "might is right" is a dangerous one to hold, I just don't think he successfully refuted what he brought up as Cohen's stance.

Then he brings up the argument that this is the way it's always been. I think appealing to tradition as justification is so obviously a terrible idea, so no qualms there. And I think what he says afterwards is important, that sometimes change for the better can require or result in massive change in society, but its still for the better.

Ultimately, I think the convincing arguments are in the latter half of the video: reducing suffering in creatures that feel suffering, not arbitrarily prioritizing some animal life over other, and being consistent with one's beliefs.

Everyone is arguing in the comment section but the general and realistic approach we can all agree on is that 'unnecessary' suffering of animals for human use should stop.

Whether it is right for us to kill animals or not, the truth is, killing animals for meat is one thing, but unnecessary suffering of the animals before their death is another. This can be seen in many forms, e.g. kept in small cages their whole life, or workers throwing chickens about or shoving poles inside pigs anuses because they had a bad day.

We all know the world cannot and will not purposely turn vegetarian in the near future. The only way to actually minimise unnecessary suffering is to decrease mass meat production (factory farming) by decreasing meat consumption.

So why don't all of you do yourselves a favour make a conscious effort to limit your meat to a healthy amount. This will have a much bigger effect than a few people here and there turning vegetarian.

Remember, there can still be a good balance between nature and humans, even with speciesism.

Well, here's my thoughts on this, and, in advance: I eat meat. Under normal circunstances though, not any animal's meat and I'll go through the differences.

So, first, I also use the discrimination of suffering and conscience. Important to note that feeling pain and suffering is not the same thing, and that we have no data to fully assess an animals awareness of his own existence as a sentient being nor if him feeling pain leads to suffering (I mean, sometimes feeling pain sometimes leads to pleasure to some ppl, myself included). We do have some pretty good clues though.
That means I don't eat cetaceans and primates, cause their brains are kinda big and research has pointed to some really out of the ordinary self awareness from these animals.
I also don't eat animals from endangered species that were hunted in their natural habitat (if they were bred for it, it's okay).
I also don't condone mistreating animals for it's own sake.

Then, I don't eat animals that I arbitrarily chose not to, like cats and rabbits. Even if dolphins were stupid AF I wouldn't eat 'em, cause they're too cute. And no, I don't find piglets to be cute. Is it inconsistent? Yes, but not really, because incosistencies only do matter where they incur harm, and there's no harm in not killing or not eating those animals.

What about treating animals differently from humans based on their differences, and considering such differences morally relevant?  For example, mice have a much larger birth rate and a much shorter life cycle than humans, and as mammals are relatively similar to humans from a physiological perspective than insects?   Mice are thus better for using for genetic testing than most animals, giving a reason to potentially use them for genetic testing.  It's not the only view on animal treatment, but it does seem to take care of some of the problems with speciesism.

I have a problem reconciling that we simultaneously share a universal ethical space with animals, and at the same time are animals. A fox eats a chicken in a way outside of ethics because it is an animal. I eat a chicken and must include myself, and the chicken in that universal ethical space that also excludes ethics in order to make an ethical decision about my actions with respect to non-ethical animals, who should be treated as though they did have an understanding of ethics, or at least the benefit of them. What is more confusing is the assertion that removing certain technology or some undefined level of civilization, that I can rejoin the non-ethical group of animals because my survival as an animal, irrespective of my reasoning skills, is now an acceptable part of the discussion. Animals will kill one another regardless of my actions outside of any ethical discussion. But that would seem to also hold me accountable, at least on some occasions, for my actions and inactions that allow for the killing or pain of animals that I could have taken steps to eliminate. The only positions that makes sense from this view is that all animal suffering is bad, especially if I make no steps to avoid it, which is nonsense because I cannot halt all suffering anywhere, or I am an animal at all times and in all ways, and my reasoning is only to be considered as it is helpful at doing whatever I can to interact with other non-reasoning animals for my survival. Otherwise pet ownership is ethically not allowable, if all pain-feeling animals should be treated by some standard that treats them as if they had reasoning capabilities or deserve the benefit of them. Pets make up a minuscule amount of the pain-feeling animals, and most of them were artificially selected to serve us. And "that's the way it's always been" is no defense. Neither is "because they are cute." The ethical stance would be forced into a statement that all animals must be free of bondage, regardless of how benevolently bondage would be, and they should all die of natural causes, which is impossible to achieve.

Interesting thought, but I have always seen this issue like this:
Cows & pigs, cats & dogs, what do these two groups have in common? Both parties are domesticated, bread to live with humans, and wouldn't last a minute in the wild. However, there is a distinct difference between the two. Cats and dogs were bred for companionship, and it is now engraved not only in their nature, but in ours to serve each other in an interesting form of symbiosis. Cattle and pigs on the other hand, were bred as a reliable source of food, and that companionship was never there. They are a prey item that we have control over. Now, there is nothing much we can do about this now, they are domesticated, so what would you do? You can't release them into the Wild. However, I do feel the need to respect our animals used for food. Their conditions in life can be poor(and that's the issue that should be fixed), but it just makes the situation worse when certain people decide not to eat the meat those animals were forced to provide. Imagine living your life in horrible conditions, being told you will be killed to feed another, then you are killed, only to never serve the purpose you were born for. We all need to eat, this is true. And the philosophy regarding the ethical treatment of non human animals is such that, on the surface, a vegetarian diet makes moral and ethical sense.
However... when we consider agriculture, we must be completely honest. Growing crops, farmers will kill any animal that comes near their produce. Rabbits, deer, kangaroos (in my native home...) etc etc - animals suffer producing the food which vegetarians eat... and then the vegetarians think they're morally superior, ignoring the fact that their diet still kills things, because the dead things don't end up on their plate.
Indeed... humankind has invented poisons (such as ratsak etc) which kill rodents slowly and painfully - a way we would never kill humans. Humankind invented the disease, mixomotosis, which infects rabbits (and doesn't discriminate between wild rabbits and Fluffy, the pet rabbit) - mixo kills rabbits slowly and painfully.
Farmers also engage in shooting birds, and spraying pesticides to kill massive numbers of insects which can disturb their crop.
How, then, does one ethically justify a vegetarian diet and complain about people eating meat? Both kill massive numbers of animals... one then discards the animals like rubbish, whilst the other uses the animals flesh, fur etc.
Which is philosophically better? A cow living on a farm, eating grass all day long (something I'm led to believe cows enjoy...), but then one day it gets put on a truck and taken to a slaughterhouse where it's stunned, then killed and cut up for meat - or eating a plate of veggies and pretending that nothing suffered, ignoring the FACT that animals have certainly suffered for those veggies to get to your plate?

It really should be a no brainer that causing suffering to an animal is immoral. But there are some things to consider. On the  basis of need, should I have to consume an animal to live healthily then absolutely my needs would trump that of the animal. Even more importantly, using an animal as a natural resource does not preclude that animal from having a generally good life. There is no reason why farms can't be humane and in many places they are. In return, at some point we'll give it a quick, painless death and eat it.

I've had an interesting observation about fish. Yes, they suffer and feel pain; that's a given. But they also have emotion. Wait.....what.....emotional fish. Your batshit crazy; is what you'd say. However, this leads to my observation. I had a tank with fish. One fish was sick, practically dead. I removed him from the tank, and put him in a smaller medical tank. He recovered and I re-introduced him back into the large, populated tank. Here's the thing: the moment he plopped back into the water, all the other fish swam up to greet him. Some even bumping him as a cat would bump heads with other cats to show affection. Those other fish reacted in a 'welcome back, how are you feeling' kinda way. These were actions by the fish, that I'd never seen or heard of before. I've looked at fish differently since then.

A great video. Best argument was that of suffering--eating meat (which in American culture means cattle, pigs, chickens, or turkeys) should be predicated on reducing the amount of suffering for those animals. However, I'd like to point out that even vegetarianism is speciesism. For example, to grow crops almost always requires drastically altering the landscape--deforestation, removal of shrubs or weeds, massive herbicide and pesticide use that decimates populations of fungus, insects, and various of invertebrates, as well as potentially removing roosts for birds. Thus, in almost any true sense, existence--the necessity of eating--requires harming and killing other living things. If we extend our empathy to cattle and rabbits, I see no clear reason not to extend it further to pine trees, beetles, caterpillars, migratory birds, etc. Entire ecosystems are altered by agriculture. Ultimately, we should be honest about the price of existence and work to mitigate suffering among ALL non-human animals, not just the ones we easily empathize with (i.e. vertebrates).

Here is a big reason to discard the idea we could just eat farmed vegetables; In order to grow enough plants to feed society we would need massive fields, similar to those we already have, farmed by heavy machines, similar to those we already use, and a total disregard for the small animals and insects that live in the ground and on those plants, which we already have.

Plainly, by the numbers we kill far more animals and insects just through growing crops than we do by slaughtering cattle and other animals for meat, leather, and other products.

If we are looking at this from a Utilitarian Perspective, then we have a moral obligation to choose ranching over farming. This is simply because the suffering of a few animals to provide food, in the form of meat, for us is less than the suffering of a great many animals to provide food, in the form of plants, for us.

My idea towards his last question of eating a pet cat is: When we consider the treatment for animals, we don't consider that for the animals really; we consider for ourselves, and fellow human-beings. (Um...until one day some non-human animals can have meaningful social discourse with us?) And we weigh things (and, to a point, even other humans) on their social value. We feel aversion when people do unethical dealings with any entity we consider of significant social value to us.

We feel different degrees of sadness when we hear a loved one, a respected celebrity, or a serial killer dies (and if one doesn't...then I'm not talking about them, just common folks), because they hold different social value to us, and that's ok. Same logic, whether you're a vegan or not, you probably have different degrees of aversion when you hear 1) people eating pork 2)people eating their own pet piglet when it dies. A pet pig holds a significant social value to its human owners, hence they're more significant to the human society than just any random pigs. The death of Cecil, and not any random pouched lion (although their deaths should raise outrage too I think) raised such a degree of outrage, is because Cecil was a symbol in his home country and beyond, hence he 's part of our society too. So when you think about it, it's really not about them; it's about ourselves, and our fellow human-beings' feelings and values.
I would even argue that racial issue really began to resolve when people of different race mingle and have social discourse together, despite the segregation that happened. Only then people consider each race to be integral to our society. If one day some aliens or the Outer Gods (any Lovecraft fan?) come to earth and raise us like cattles, keep us as pets, or treat us under some otherworldly moral standard different from ours, it would certainly be immoral to us, but to them? Probably wouldn't - unless we can have social discourse with them and we become socially relevent to each other.

My take on the issue is that meat does taste good and DOES play an important part in human diets, but these things do not justify the torture/abuse of the animals that make that meat. A cow should have a good life regardless of whether or not it will be slaughtered. And when they are slaughtered, it should be painless, ideally in way we would kill one of our own, or indeed, our pets, in the interest of minimal pain, but does not contaminate the meat.

Granted, my argument simply cannot be applied to humans. I realize this is 'speciesist' but that is the nature of nature; we are inherently justified for killing other animals for our own benefit because it does not hamper our species' propagation, and I believe that is hard-wired into us and every living thing. That being said, I will not allow my argument to be used to justify killing or torturing other people's pets. If a cow or a pig, or indeed anything, is raised as a pet and not as a food source, it is NOT justified to kill it for your own benefit.

TL;DR #2:
There is nothing wrong in killing an animal for your own benefit, provided it was cared for correctly, and that its death was painless, it was not a human, and it's specific purpose in life was to be eaten in the end.

NOTE: I did not include hunting wild creatures in my argument on purpose, as I haven't found what I would call a good foundation to base my current stance on. Let's just keep this to domesticated/captive-born/farmed animals for now.

I think it's more to do with our interaction with animals on an individual level. The reason we don't eat fluffy is because we know her, we care for her, and she's brought joy to our lives and us to hers, and we know her as somewhat of an equal. Meanwhile, if I'm served chicken that I know was from a living breathing suffering animal in the middle of buttfuck nowhere, yeah, thinking on it, I might feel a bit of remorse, but I mean, I don't know that chicken. It was never given a name. It's not much to me. That said, I don't think that's justification. I'm not saying I don't have justification, but stopping there would be a misstep. It's like saying that you're OK with thousands of people dying in a war because you don't know them. That's the thought process of the stereotypical evil politician on his big podium advocating for WWII. Which I mean, in that sense, there is a difference in kind, as wars are typically fought over ideals, but it's the thought that other creatures of relevant intelligence are expendable that I find deplorable.

Now, there are two main reasons I think I and most other people can justify eating meat. Well, kinda one, but it has two sides I guess. Basically, it's the idea of ignorance, which no, normally isn't at all justification, but hear me out on this one. Let's start with the one that is far less popular, and that I wouldn't advocate for. The idea that the animals exist on a different world, unalike our own entirely.

The average person, when they imagine a cow farm, or a pig farm, picture this big open fenced off field for the cows to frolic in, and grass to eat, and space to move. And while that's not what happens a lot of the time, it perpetuates the idea that farm animals are living in an entirely different world, and when their time comes, we harvest what's left, and boom. It's on your plate. It views them as something entirely separate from humans that we just benefit from. Unfortunately, we all know this isn't true. But that's no reason to drop your steak knife and grab a sign to go protest your local farm. No, I still think there's a reason I am comfortable with eating meat. And that's the fact that the animals we eat do not have a certain drive that humans do. Hear me out on this one...

A cow likes open space. A cow likes to eat grass. A cows main goal in life is to reproduce. A cow however, does not want representation in congress. You see what I mean? A cow is, a cow. And its motivations and drives are less complicated than a humans. They may not necessarily be simple creatures, but they're not exactly planning rebellions. I draw your attention to near the beginning of the video where the treatment of livestock was compared to the treatment of slaves during the 1800s. I don't think this holds water. Because if you set a slave free, they will grow and learn in their lifetime to have pursuits other than reproducing. If you gave a cow citizenship, and a house, and everything a normal citizen has, including putting it through school, yeah it may pick up some habits just from repeated exposure, I won't pretend like it won't, but it's not going to start working a 9 to 5. It will still continue it's simple and happy existence of eating grass, roaming around, and continuing it's species. It would be like if the slaves back when were freed, and upon having them be told that they just went "Oh... alright." And just kept on working. No demand for better treatment, except obviously protesting violence, but for the most part, nothing much would change. Purely hypothetical, and yeah, some things don't exactly fit perfectly, but I think it's easy enough to pick up what I'm putting down.

Intelligence is the principle of differentiation. The reason the cognitively disabled person fails to serve as a defeater for the argument is that such people still have the basic capacity for intelligence (or more specifically, for reason). The fact that they are hindered by some physical deformity from expressing that capacity doesn't change the fact that they have it by nature. In other words, to use the classical definition, a human is a rational animal. Kittens just aren't. Now, morality and moral obligations are directly connected to reason, to rationality. So that which is rational (by nature) is a moral agent. That which is arational is not a moral agent. Kittens, dogs, pigs, these are arational creatures. They are, then, not moral agents and therefore our use of them is not governed by morality. It is, rather, governed by prudence and general principles of stewardship. Moreover, since part of being rational is having a general respect for life (a disposition that favors life), we should have a general desire to reduce suffering even in non-rational entities (e.g., cows and chickens). So we can definitely say that the treatment of animals may well be "inhumane" and thus be immoral--not because the animal itself has any intrinsic rights being violated but because to cause unjustified suffering is irrational. It is inhumane. It is actually, then, a sin against humanity (so to speak) to be cruel to animals.

I'm sure there's some people in the comment section that are willing to go vegan/vegetarian for animals rights because they believe they deserve some degree of respect that humans get, but also believe that fetuses aren't humans and thus it's okay to kill them (or terminate if you're too uncomfortable with "kill") because it's convenient. Isn't one of the themes of this video (or, more broadly, philosophy in general) that people should be consistent with their views and actions?

I was wondering if Hank might also talk about the Kantian perspective of the treatment of animals. Turns out he didn't, so here goes.

Immanuel Kant laid out a philosophical groundwork that had two maxims: the first is: "Act only according to that maxim whereby you can at the same time will that it should become a universal law" (only do things which you would be okay if everyone else in the world did it, under the same principles). The second is: "Act in such a way that you treat humanity, whether in your own person or in the person of any other, never merely as a means to an end, but always at the same time as an end" (don't use people as tools without also considering their humanity). He said this because we humans are "Rational Beings"; that is, these rules apply because humans are self-determining agents, and must therefore be treated as free creatures with their liberty endorsed.

I was wondering how this would apply to animals; since simpler creatures such as fish or chicken are definitely not rational beings, is it perhaps okay to deny them the right of liberty, and hence use them as mere means? Of course, they still do feel pain, and hence I agree that slaughtering or hunting should be as painless as possible. Even better, synthetically produced protein can be used as an alternative to eating meat, once the technology has advanced. But on the basis that some animals may not have any agency or observable consciousness, could we not only treat humans as higher creatures than animals, but also treat more cognitively aware animals as above others? After all, most of us would regard a dog as a higher creature than an ant (though this is an extreme example, the principle remains).

Personification, pure and simple. Humans like some animals more than others. We like dogs, cats, and other traditional pets because we attribute them to being fun, innocent, loyal, caring, etc. Essentially, we project or notice certain qualities about them that we value. By contrast, we rarely think of cows, chickens, or pigs outside of their purpose as farm animals.

When Cecil and Harambe were shot, people were offended because of the circumstance. Harambe was in a zoo, would have lived a long peaceful life, if not for the child that fell in and the reaction of the staff. Cecil was in an animal in a national park, and was hunted purely for sport. He was also a member of a species which was declared endangered later that year.

As the video pointed out, you might consider self defense and/or other factors to be justification. However that doesn't apply here. Cecil was killed for a trophy and bragging rights. Harambe was shot, because an irresponsible parent neglected to stop their child from climbing into a gorilla enclosure.

As I said, we like some animals more than we like others and it shows in the manner with which we treat them.

Having only watched a little bit of the video thusfar. I think we should reconcile our differences in behavior with different animals by 2 main criteria. Their "level of ability to understand complex concepts" which I categorize as non-sapient, sapient, semi sentient, and sentient; and their ability to sense pain. I don't feel bad about killing or even "torturing" bugs (fly tape is a cruel death) because they don't feel pain and are non-sapient.
To me: pain means that we should avoid harming it, but for the greater good we may experiment. But to me anything that is semi sentient or sentient can experience "an intensifying of mental and physical discomfort due to the expectation of future harm" or suffering, and I think it is morally indefensible to purposefully cause suffering in any way to any being.
Do I think chickens, deer, cows, or most fish suffer? No, I doubt they do. Do I think pigs suffer? Quite possibly, but I'm not sure. Do I think dogs, monkeys, or dolphins suffer? Yes I'm pretty sure they do. It's wrong to cause them suffering. That being said if you have to forcefully restrain your dog, or you smack it once to get it's attention, it's pain for the greater good not long term suffering.

A maybe-productive addition to this conversation I can make from having taken a class taught by Peter Singer as an undergrad - he (and lots of other utilitarians) factor modern science about animal cognition into their judgments about what is ethical behavior.
One potentially important factor is why we consider it a moral wrong to kill a person. One popular response is, "Because we're taking away somebody's future." In that case, in addition to suffering, it's ethically relevant to consider whether or not the being we're killing to eat actually has a conception of its own future.
Our best understanding right now is that most mammals do in fact have a concept of the future, on some level, making killing them immoral. However, other animals, including fish and insects, do not, making eating them quite possibly moral so long as we do not cause them to suffer when we kill them. That's why I (personally) believe that a pescetarian diet is a perfectly ethical choice.

The subject of moral speciesism is important, as an extension of humanism.
One principle that guides me in this is scaling. I measure creatures by their amount of difference from me.
intelligence and empathy are keys here, but there is no dichotomy, as we consider a spectrum of beings:
related human > human > ape > mammal > bird > fish and reptilian > ...

one justification for this non-universality is simple: if we would not allow it, we can reach weird implications.
for example, it would imply that our desires are equivalent to those of single cellular organisms.
the desire to avoid pain was developed in central nervous system creatures from similar desires of simpler beings.
since we cannot possibly give the same amount of effort to please bugs as mammals, we can agree there is a well ordering
of importance of creatures, even if we cant really enumerate it precisely.

practicality allows us to go further, and consists of considerations of human thinking, and our own capability to reject enjoyment (a need of itself, even if lesser than the will to live). this for example means that we can punish a person for hurting animals themselves, not just their owners livelihood and emotions. it also means there is a number of ape lives that one human life is worth.

I'm rather swayed by the intelligence argument, or rather, the contributions argument. Humans have a capacity to active contribute to stories and music and constructions and a systematic understanding of the universe no other life we know can (with the possible exception of other primates). That's my reason to separate other animals from humans. The well-being of a contributing human may be affected by the well-being of an impaired child or even pet (though the excessive valuing of pets is a problem), and so they have the same protection, though indirectly.

Something not often talked about is where the lower cutoff is for animals. Surely eating entirely passive shellfish is ok? Are insects conscious enough to be given the same respect as humans? Humans don't know enough about neuroscience to call hard lines yet, so going off of potential (direct or indirect) makes more sense to me. Comes with free incentives to improve standard of living worldwide.

Singer is absolutely right when he says that animals deserve better treatment, but he is wrong when he says there is no morally relevant difference between humans and other animals. Imagine there was a fire, and a firefighter had to run into a house and only had time to save either a canary in its cage or a human baby, it would not only be the right choice to take the baby, we would be morally appalled if the firefighter chose the canary.

The fact is, there are differences when it comes to the depth and complexity of the human experience. I know this sounds dangerously anthropocentric, but bear with me here. The reason the firefighter is morally obliged to save the baby is because of the difference on the experience that child can potentially achieve.

The thing is, this isn't an issue on which we should apply a has moral worth / does not have moral worth tag on living beings, we should recognize that there are different subcategories of moral worth, each with its own guarantees to the proportion that that specific living thing deserves.

What this means is that animals that feel pain are automatically put on a relatively high rung of the moral ladder, and there are basic guarantees of treatment we should extend to them for the mere fact of them being able to feel pain. How we identify pain in animals is another debate alltogether, but there are some well known indicators.

Animals that not only feel pain but show signs of personality, and in some instances, a more rudimentary form of consciousness, are also assigned higher places in the list. Dolphins and primates are considered non-human animals for good reason, they have demonstrated enough individuallity and complexity that we recognize their increased moral worth.

This is also supported by the way we treat insects. Just think if why we pay no consideration to the ants we walk on. They are alive aren't they? Why were they not considered in the video? What separates an ant from us, and more importantly, from other animals?

They are placed in a lower rung in the moral worth scale because on the one hand they can't feel pain (as far as we know), and they resemble more biological machines than actual animals. The behaviour of an ant is completely indistinguishable from any other ant, they react in the most basic ways that hint at the stimulus - reaction dinamic at play here. There is no conscious experience anywhere in the chain, not that we know of at least, and that has a huge role in determining their moral worth.

There is a qualitative difference between being an ant or most insects, and being a pig. None of us would save an ant over a lion or a condor, or a blue whale. Well what I am arguing is that the reasons we would never choose the ant goes beyond the fact that one of them feels pain, but is also, as illustrated by the firefighter thought experiment, because we recognize the cognitive differences between living beings.

Just to be clear, I think animals deserve extremely better treatment than they are currently getting. No animal should have to be tortured in order for us to satisfy our needs. We could perfectly well treat animals with the amount of humanity that they deserve, and we are in fact morally obligated to do so.

This does not mean however that all animals are equal to us, because there are differences that exist beyond the fact of feeling pain that I believe Singer wrongly ignores.

Don't eat pigs anymore because of their level of intellect... except bacon.

We need to stop fretting over the individual cases of animal ethics and start prioritising the success of the entire species.

Cows and chickens are purposely bred to be consumed or to harvest byproducts from. Their populations are completely controlled by humans and they, as a species, are at no risk of becoming endangered or extinct. Similarly, the mallard duck and fallow deer are extremely common in America and Eurasia.
However, the lion is classified as 'vulnerable' so if a person were to hunt them for sport, not only does it mean a decrease in their population and one step closer to extinction, it also 'normalises' this and shows that if you have the money, it is possible to get a hunting permit for this outrageous 'hobby'.
The same goes for any rare wild species not specifically bred for meat or hide such as wild elephants killed for their tusks or sunbears abused for bile in their gall bladders.

However, sustained animal cruelty (slaughtering is not animal cruelty) is despicable and should not be tolerated for any species, whether wild or bred.

Hank I understand and respect your biases and your emotional turmoil over you own deep seated love of meat and pet ownership, but it has no place in this series. Singer (and his ilk) has provided exactly zero compelling arguments for the treatment of non-human animals because they all stem from the same fallacy, false equivalency. Non-human animals are not humans, I firmly believe that statement to be non-controversial, so why must we give the same regard to non-human animals as the human animal. Now I come from this as a pet owner myself, and I love my pets, I would visit John Wick levels of retribution on anyone who harmed my pets. But they are not human, I have never made that mistake, their needs and my own needs are so wildly different beyond the basics that we enter the realm of Blue and Orange morality. Treating non-human animals as though they are human and possess similar emotions and level of cognition to a human is called anthropomorphism and this is tantamount to animal abuse because you are ignoring the needs of your animals to fulfill your own self-centered sense of moral righteousness. It is still possible to treat non-human animals with respect and decency while fulfilling their needs as non-human animals, and our own as human animals, but pretending they are human is the same type of paternalist thinking that lead to us treating Africans as animals in the days of slavery; we think we know best when we know nothing at all.  If you think dog fighting is wrong then we should end combat sports for humans, if you equate an animals intelligence to that of an infant or a handicapped person you have just diminished the people in that scenario to that of non-human animals, if you are concerned with animals suffering then you should be working equally as hard to resettle refugees, and fight poverty and hunger. If a dog bites a human should they be euthanized without trial? Or should the dog be represented in a court of law with a jury of its peers and, if found guilty, sentenced to imprisonment and rehabilitated, executed? And don't even dare start on about internal consistency towards the treatment of non-human animals when we can't even be consistent about our treatment of the human ones.
