I don't think this is in the realm of philosophy, so I don't blame you for not mentioning this, but I do think there is an argument to be made from the evolutionary point of view. Domesticated species have evolved to fill a very specific niche- human "companionship". But this companionship must be reciprocal, or else they would just be parasitical to humans. So dogs can be service animals, cats hunt vermin, llamas carry packs... but most species have been domesticated to be consumed by humans. People forget that there is no such thing as a "wild cow" (aurochs), and wild horses are highly endangered. So these animals have also ensued that their species survives by becoming domesticated, and in return we get to consume them. I think we should definitely limit animal consumption to domesticated species (no wild animals), and we should make sure they suffer as little as possible when they're sacrificed.

My problem with the "game hunting" in general is it's a pride thing. At its core, I personally find it illogical. Hunting for food? That's one thing. DISCLAIMER: As written text lacks the ability to put emphasis (as exemplified there) on words and phrases which is so important in the conveying of meaning in spoken text, I use bold text as a substitute for that ability. Therefore, any abundance of bold text in this post should not be viewed as any emotional instability or otherwise as an indication of irrational behaviour on my part, but instead as an attempt to convey as much meaning as possible with my words in this limited format.








A difficult topic, certainly. But nonetheless, here is my attempt at a response.




Equal Consideration of Interests, as you call it, should of course go all ways it can. You rightly pointed out that owning or eating a Human Being [or Fluffy the cat, for that matter -- but I'll get back to her] is seen as morally abhorrent, and thus owning or eating a non-Human Animal should be seen the same way according to the Principle of the Equal Consideration of Interests.
However, you neglected to consider the case which goes the other 'way round: if, say, the consumption for culinary or nutritional considerations (i.e. "eating") of non-Human Animals by Humans is seen as morally abhorrent, shouldn't the eating of non-Human Animals by other non-Human Animals seen the same way? After all, isn't the point of Philosophy, in your words at least, that we should be internally consistent? Why should the catching (and often torturing, no less) and subsequent consumption of the flesh of a mouse by Fluffy the cat -- there she is again -- be OK when we view similar treatment of Humans and non-Human Animals alike by Humans as morally abhorrent? Or, alternatively, if we are OK with Fluffy doing what she does to the mouse, why shouldn't we be OK with what Humans do to non-Human Animals?
Speaking of that line of thought, the thing about "This is the way it's always been.".... Not only has it been this way for the life-span of the Human Race, but it has been this way for the entirety of the existence of Life on Earth. You could say it's the "natural order of
things", in a way, and that there is no reason to change something which has literally been the case for as long as there WERE cases to consider. I'm not sure whether I'd say this is a good argument myself, but it is certainly one to consider. And, most importantly, to not misrepresent by saying it only applies to the time Humans were on Earth, as supposed to the time Life Itself was on Earth.

My own, personal answer is that, just as I wouldn't want non-Human Animals to be tortured by Humans, I'd stop Fluffy [or Munky, for that matter, who was my cat who died a little under a year ago] from torturing mice if I knew of a way to convince them. However, as I am perfectly OK with Fluffy, Munky or any other cat eating [and catching, for that matter, if the kill would be instantaneous] mice, I also have no trouble with Humans eating non-Human Animals.
I do, however, think that the use of non-Human Animals for needs other than consumption of the flesh for eating purposes -- say, testing Cosmetics -- should be moved away from with utmost haste as soon as humanly [he he] possible for the moral reasons discussed in this video and above in this post. I also think the ownership of Animals for the purposes of doing something with them that would kill them should be moved away from as much as possible as soon as possible, and not just for the Philosophical and Moral reasons that apply -- owning and feeding a cow, for example, to the point of raising it so that it's meat may be consumed or new cows can be born is equivalent to many, many miles of driving a really old and heavily CO2-emitting car. Not sure how many miles anymore, but I do remember it's a lot. On the other hand, we are perfectly OK with Humans working for other Humans, as long as the working conditions -- and, should they be housed by the Company, living conditions -- are of a high standard and they get payed for what they do. Similarly, it could be argued that, say, keeping a Cow for the purposes of extracting her milk is justifiable, as long as the "working conditions" and living conditions are of a high quality [so the Factory Farms are, indeed, completely and utterly unacceptable and should be banned with utmost haste] and they get rewarded in some way for their "work" of producing and giving milk.

Okay here is how I determine the how animals should be treated.
1. If they are smart enough to be self aware and communicate using language then they should be protected under human laws. I.e Dolphins/whales, elifants and Primates
2. If they show clear signs of emotional awareness they should be protected from harm. I.e Cats, dogs, and other mammals kept as pets.
3. If they do not harm humans and are not a necessary source of food for the population they should be protected from hunting. I.e any Non domesticated farm animal with the exemption of pests/bugs.
4. If they are a food source they should be used only to meet the demand and given a humane life. I.e Domesticated farm animals.
5. All animals that lack purpose, intelligence, and only serve as an annoyance or health risk to humans deserve no protections. I.e almost all bugs/rodents (bees and a few others are exemptions.

I don't know, there's something odd about this. A cow couldn't decide to eat me if it needed to, nor could a shark have a moral obligation against eating me. I don't believe it's about whether or not a being can suffer (though I believe it is our duty to keep suffering, while an essential element of the natural world, to a minimum) so much as it is about whether or not that being can make a moral decision. Slaves can make moral decisions, can put their morality over their own survival (or vice versa). I don't doubt that some chimpanzees can as well. Some plants can suffer and we eat them, too (though fruit is designed to be eaten, I think). As a second note -- I think the point about not wanting to eat your dead cat comes down to the classification of that animal's utility. That cat is cute and has kept you company; it is not meant for eating. I think some animals can be meant for some things and some animals can be meant for others, that's how most things work. There's no need to get all absolutist about it.

To me what matters is how we treat the animal while it's alive, how the animal meets its end, and whether the animal would be sufficiently mourned. As long as death is not anticipated by the dying and instantaneous, I don't think it is wrong or qualifies as suffering to the being that is killed, though the loss of said being could invoke suffering in others (within certain elements of reason), or at least the suffering in such case is very minimal to the benefits acquired by it's death by means of food/other materials. As long as animals raised for consumption are treated well (which I have a high standard for, generally that animals raised in captivity be subject to less stress and pain than they would experience in the wild)) and won't cause substantial grief (which killing/separation of babies in several species can cause to their mothers) I don't think it is wrong to do so. I apply the same standards to humans, though with humans it is much stricter due to the fact that humans (and certain other animals, like dogs) provide more utility alive than they would in their death.

Eating animals and being philosophically consistent.
The reasons for respecting other humans are 3, The ethical consideration for their being a sentient being, and secondly, for being human-like. the 3rd will be at the end of this comment. Some animals are human like, others are not, this is why we protect animals we have high degrees of empathy for, and we eat the rest. something being human-like, or easily anthropomorphised, is an in-built and non-ethically based part of our biology, and our own biology is factored into what is and isn't ethical when it comes to acts of violence anyway. Our consideration of some animals and not others, is simply being consistent in that other pre-existing stance.

The 3rd reason, is for animals that are purpose-made. Cows? Domesticated. Dogs? Domesticated. Cats? Domesticated. Sheep? Domesticated. These are animals which had no human-like qualities of in-built empathy in us, which we have for thousands and thousands of years, been selectively breeding. They are UTILITIES. Cats? made to be pets. Dogs? Made for hunting, helping to tend cattle, being pets. Cows? Livestock. sheep? Livestock. these animals are wildly different from their wild counterparts, and those differences are what allow us to treat them as utility. That's not to say "that's why it's okay to eat cows", but rather to say "That's why it's okay to keep cats and dogs as pets, and to treat them more like people'.

Privilege : a special right, advantage, or immunity granted or available only to a particular person or group of people.
Emphasis is on Granted here. A Privilege is granted by a 3rd party, but in the case of survival of the fittest, There is no 3rd party to grant privilege to a victor.

Positions like that are not granted to a privileged class, They are earned for hard work and effort. Task done successfully in order to maintain placement.

If a species is unable to dominate all others, then it is by definition not at the top of the hierarchy.

The use of the term "Privileged" in this context, Is a fallacy.

I do think our higher capacity for understanding and suffering merits us more moral consideration than lesser creatures. And this goes on a spectrum, a dolphin may have more rights than a tuna, which has more rights than an ant which has more rights than a plant and it has more rights than a bacterium. But is there such a thing as a victimless crime? Even those lowly bacteria are designed to reproduce and spread, harvesting them in some manner and killing them is obviously against what they would do if left alone and what is ideal for them. Plants, which vegans gulp down with much gusto also don't want to be eaten. Obviously so, when a plant is cut it enters a sort of panic mode and releases chemicals which set other plants on high alert. A dumb animal can feel pain and that sucks, a smarter animal can probably experience psychological damage.

So to me there is no victimless crime but some indeed are less equal than others, at least until we reach a more perfect world. Smartest animals deserve most consideration, things with nerves after that then plants then the lowliest forms of life. Rare forms of life also deserve special protection. Of course that "things different than me can be abused" is a dangerous precedent so ultimately the most ideal thing would be a kind of techno-food, lab grown meat AND lab grown plant matter. Designed in such a way to avoid any kind of suffering or distress.

Personally, I simply think humans as they are are doing the right thing, and that's primarily treating this as an economic issue. Placing a cat or dog on a high table of concern as apposed to a pig or cow is reasonable, because the emotional attachment we add to the pet generally increases the well being of the owner, whether it be by bringing happiness, or enforcing a domestic structure, and so on. Naturally any animal can fit the role of pet, generally speaking, so which animal gains such a position is culturally dictated.

The same can be applied to farm animals, who instead of serving as an developmental tool, serve as a resource. Animals that don't provide an effective economic boost don't become farm animals. Hence why we're not making farms for tigers, or polar bears. Sure we have zoos, but their value just doesn't compare, and thus these animals can be widely disregarded.

And in regards to suffering, I believe it unreasonable that we should make the assumed argument that less suffering is better. Suffering is ultimately the only blockade between progress and stagnation. Take the dodos for example: With nothing hunting them, and no ways to suffer, their species stagnated, and didn't have the tools required to adapt when animals that did arrive in their habitat. Suffering is the most memorable, more primal emotion within all thing that can feel, which is why we do all we can to avoid it. However, it is irresponsible to denounce suffering as nothing more than a vile bi-product of what is considered 'wrong'.

Without suffering, species die, and generations of children grow up apathetic and unconcerned, needing to make up their own versions of suffering as the human mind cannot sustain itself without it.

Usually my reasoning is that I base morality on a social contract and the fact that humans are a social animal and some rules are needed for society to function. Animals are not bound by those rules (so that it is not immoral for a bear to kill a fish or a human) - they might have their own rules and their own societies and might not.
We can get attached to animals or decide to protect them for human interests though. Or avoid excessive cruelty for our own sake - but we have no moral obligation toward animals because they have no moral obligation towards us.
I think that where it's possible to include a being in human society it should be done. Where it cannot be done that's a morally relevant difference. That's what morality is based on and used for.

Here's a justification that I use, because I think it's the best solution for the most people. We, as humans, learned to specialize. This more than any other thing moved us to non-tribal systems and into what we call "Culture". I don't mean good culture, just culture at all. I can focus on one thing while you focus on something else, and because we work together neither of us goes hungry. This has led (at extreme) to the ability to specialize in computers, and more specifically computers that make vehicles that go to the moon. We are able to make this progress because everyone (animals included) are doing their part. Without bovine insulin, smart people die and don't move us as far forward as we could go. Our great advancements have been due in large part to the fact that we subjugated, experimented on, and used non-human animals. Without them we died younger, can't specialize as well. And advance slower. Us using them moved the greater "us" forward. Think of it like taxing those with money to feed the poor. You may not be willing, but it sure does a whole lot of good.

An interesting argument, but how far are you willing to take it? 

Harvesting plants for eating, for example, has an animal death toll.  Mice, snakes, and other small field dwelling animals inhabit cropland, and many are killed during mechanized harvesting.  Large combine harvester equipment kills countless animals during normal operation.  They may not be killed for food, but they are killed as a result of obtaining food.  By this manner, even a vegan diet can indirectly cause animal deaths. 

What about insects?  Most plants are treated with pesticides, which kill countless insects before they can destroy our crops.  Is killing a swarm of a million locusts the same as slaughtering a million cattle, philosophically speaking? 

Even organic grown crops still fight, kill, or at the very least repel pests, they just don't use chemical treatments.  By preventing pests from consuming our crops, even with natural methods, are we not causing their suffering by denying them sustenance?   

What about when a mosquito lands on your arm, and you swat it?  Or killing a spider in your kitchen?  Is that the same as strangling a puppy?  A life has been taken, after all. 

I've read about some monastery where they do take this view as far as possible, insofar as they don't kill anything, sweep the floor in front of them as they walk to keep from crushing unseen bugs, and only eat fruit after it falls off of trees, so as not to harm the tree by harvesting food early.  Does that sound like a reasonable lifestyle?

I have a two-stage answer to that. One of those you discussed: Need.
The other is to further differentiate the non-category of non-human animals. Every species has to be evaluated on its own, because we evaluate humans on their own. Humans cannot not be evaluated as a category of their own because of sentient agency giving them a choice in their treatment of other species, leading to the necessity of ethics in the first place. This of course establishes sentience as a relevant discriminator and when we consequentially use that on the whole of the animal kingdom (and on lifeforms as a group at large) species by species, what we get is a gradient.
Humans at the top, followed by a long line starting with primates, maybe octopuses, and some seemingly random groups of other mammals and birds and ending somewhere at the level of animals with no (jellyfish, corals) or very rudimentary (starfish, sea urchines) nervous systems, if not with plants and mushrooms.
The problem is, evolution being gradual, there is no logical cut-off point here. Plants are generally agreed to have no sentience while humans are agreed to have (to keep it brief) full sentience. Everything in between is a problem.
The approach does, however, comfortably save puppies and kittens, because their respective species are members of carnivora, one of the mammal groups rather high on the sentience gradient (though about as high as pigs, so, yeah, no bacon for me). The divisor is a tough line to draw, but luckily there is large gap filled with animals rarely considered edible in between chicken and salmon, so at least it is easy to draw a line somewhere in the vast realm between these points on the slider. Also, I don't think there has been much research on the sapience or sentience of different fish species, so this is where it gets hard anyway. I do realize that is being lazy, but this is why I consider the line I draw preliminary.

We routinely kill bacteria and arachnids who live on our skin and in our hair. They cause no harm to us (unless you happen to be allergic to their waste) but we still think it's okay to have a shower and remove these organisms from their habitat, almost certainly killing them in the process. Bacteria have no nervous system at all, but how complex does a nervous system have to be for us to consider it worthy of saving? Is pain the threshold?

What about scientific research? Model organisms are used routinely because it's faster and cheaper to study them than to study humans directly. Think about studies on longevity: in less than 3 years you can have a sturdy portfolio of data on life expectancy of many C. elegans mutant variants under a multitude of environmental conditions. The same study in humans would take at least 2 or 3 generations. Does that make it okay to use non-human animals in ways that would probably be considered wrong in humans? Humans can give consent, but can other animals? Probably not, at least not in the nuanced and informed way that we expect people to consider the question of consent.

Here's one. We act morally to moral agents. Animals aren't moral agents. These two sentences (sans vegans) everyone should agree with. It probably depends on what you define as a moral agent. Mine is those people who participate in the social group to whence that morality is confined. This is why it's a social construct. Most of the time that social group is society, so our conceptions of fairness, justice, etc. are rooted here. But not all the time. Why do I feel uncomfortable eating my dead cat? Because that cat and myself formed a social group in the form of a pet-owner relationship, making both of us moral agents within that group. This group needn't have the same moral rules as any other group, but what both agents get out of participation will shape those rules.

As an anthropologist, I often see the idea of Human is Top Predator.
As the theory goes, humans are in an ecological niche, that really any organism can fill, and that all predators serve a role of balance in nature. We have the position of Top Predator because we can kill literally any organism on Earth. The higher up the food chain, the more responsibilities to nature you have. As Top Predator, humans are expected to treat other organisms, whether that be plant or non-human animal, with respect to their lives and their own ecological positions; to never abuse those we eat nor imperil their populations. When it comes to other predators, there is a unique sense of respect, as we both have a similar job for creating balance (so don't save Bambi you specist).

The Top Predator position expects humans to administer a unique kind of stewardship. This is why, historically, the Cherokee would give the forests prescribed burnings (which in Appalachia prevents super forest fires and encourage species that rely on forest fires to survive). It is because that is our ecological role, to support any organism we can kill, otherwise we wouldn't be a good Top Predator of balance and be more of a destructive force without recourse. Because we are Top Predator, we owe it to developing and exploring our moral intelligence to better support the Earth.

These last couple of episodes have taken a more biased turn. Not that I don't agree with the study of moral obligations, one of the things I love about philosophy, and this series in general, is that I'm left with really good arguments on both sides and a lot to think about. For me the far more interesting question isn't if we should treat animals ethically, but the demarcations where it becomes okay to not treat them well.

For example, in this video other animals that we happen to eat (and are delicious) are offered as the only animals that we negatively effect. But this not the case. Is it right for me to remove a colony of fire ants from some property that I own so I can build my own house? Both I and the ants just want a place to live, and they were there first, but I want to build a large house and I can't have a colony of fire ants next to it. it's not a need, because I could easily live in an apartment rather than my new house, so is it okay for me to exterminate the colony of millions of animals just so I can have a grossly overly sized McMansion?

Does it matter if the animals were deliberately evolved to provide food or satisfy some other human need? A pet dog is provided food and shelter and it seems quite happy in its existence, but it is still not free to leave and pursue it's own interests and it's kept on a leash or in a cage. For all intents and purposes, it's a slave. It's job is to provide me companionship. Is it right to keep an animal like the pet cat in the video simply because it brings humans pleasure? If my pet dog failed to adequately provide me companionship (if it was just an angry disagreeable dog) can I have it taken to the pound? What if it's eventual fate is that it's exterminated? Is it right to kill an animal purely because it pees on my bed every day when I go to work?

On the intelligence answer, while it might be true than some primates are smarter than some profoundly disabled humans it is not true (as far as I am aware) that any cattle are as smart as that.

As such the discounting of the intelligence criteria, as phrased here, seems to make a false equivalence between some animals and others. Not saying it's necessarily wrong, just not supported by the way you've put it here.

Btw, my preferred answer is utilitarian but not based on individual pain (tl;dr if you want people to stop eating meat, make animals used as livestock hold cultural significance beyond being a food source):

Morality is made up by our culture and as such it makes some sense to say one is given moral protections in proportion to how much one has the capacity to influence our culture. Humans get a free pass because humans influence other humans either directly or through clearly demonstrable bonds of empathy.

Pets impact significantly on the lives of the humans they live with and this confers many protections on to them, animals that share a species with animals kept as pets get some protections in proportion to how common it is to have them as a pet. We don't eat our pets' corpses because the pet is morally a pseudo-member of our culture and has gained the "don't eat your dead" protection.*

Non-human animals which are otherwise sufficiently intelligent (e.g. primates, dolphins) to express their own desires and actively cooperate with us to get them can interact directly with human cultures and gain protection directly from this capacity. Other non-human animals are granted some protections when the animals which communicate with us empathize with them and their treatment impacts how the non-human animals animals who interact with us behave.

Conclusion: if you want people to eat less meat I suggest you make them care about the rich lives of cows, pigs and chickens, have more people take them in as pets or demonstrate that they can have a meaningful impact on human culture in a role other than as a food source.

My justification for mistreatment of animals is simply to consider the alternatives. If consumer products or drugs weren't tested on animals prior to sale then there would be far more toxic products/drugs being used by the general populace and since the general populace is not under laboratory conditions it is likely far more adverse effects would occur before people realised the problem and managed to recall the product hence smart animal testing actually decreases the harm caused by products/drugs in the long run. Similarly scientific research done on animals has hugely reduced suffering of not just humans but animals as well so over the long run it results in a net harm reduction. For meat production the question is a bit less clear, if people didn't eat meat then the animals used in meat production would never have been born - e.g. as our use of horses for work/transport has declined the global horse population has plummeted. Morally is is better for an animal to be eaten or to have never been born?

I am a spiciest, and a meat eater, and my philosophical argument is one of "purpose".

I give preferential treatment to certain non-human animals like cats and dogs, because it's not their purpose to be eaten. Their purpose is to be companions, and more in certain other cases (e.g. dogs guiding the blind, being used to find pray during hunts, etc.).

Similarly with wild animals - they don't serve a purpose in a human society, so they should be given a default treatment of "support", i.e. it's wrong to harm them in any way, unless they pose a treat to humans or animals they own.

Farm animals like chicken, cows and pigs on the other hand, are bred for the express purpose of being food, giving milk and eggs, etc. so as long as we keep their numbers stable and minimize their suffering while they are alive, it's OK to eat them afterwards.

Now, of course, there's a counter argument to be made for "Who ultimately defines the purpose of each species? Why should any one species impose its own interpretation of a purpose onto other species?", and that's a fair argument. My answer to that is "species that can communicate with one another define the purposes of other species, and should resolve conflicting cases between each other's interpretations, and default to supporting each other's species".

For example, we're already at a point where we don't consider dolphins to be used for eating, and there's ongoing research in trying to understand the relatively recently discovered dolphin language. If one day we can communicate fluently with dolphins, they probably won't care about our interpretation on land animals, but they might oppose our insistence of eating certain species of fish that they use for some as of yet unknown purpose, or just other species that are their preferred food. In that event, I think humanity should be morally obligated to help dolphins domesticate their preferred fish species, and ask them to help protect all other wild species. Meanwhile, we could share the domesticated species of fish, giving preference to them being dolphin food, since we have other options.

And if one day we're attacked by aliens who can't communicate with us, and start harming us because their interpretation of us is that we're their food, then it's our right to try and protect ourselves, BUT said aliens wouldn't technically be morally "wrong", since we can't communicate, and thus we can't just say "don't eat us, eat chickens instead; We breed them for that purpose".

I have a serious problem with the end of this video. The flash philosophy claimed that you will almost certainly be horrified by the though of eating your dead cat, but that is far from a closed statement. A decade or so back, I remember a local news story about a Tongan family facing scrutiny because they killed and ate their dog. People who thought as I believe Hank would, that this was a horrifying thing to do, Seemed to just assume that they were objectively right. The problem is, they were actively ignoring a group of which I was a member, a reasonably large group who saw nothing wrong. They didn't draw out the animal's death, they kept it quick. They didn't abuse their dog, they loved it. The difference, it turned out, was purely cultural. Turns out their culture treated all pets like we treat pet pigs and cows: They animal is taken care of, the family develops a bond, and when the animal nears the end of its life, it's killed for food.

Sometimes feelings like the idea of eating a dead pet being horrifying isn't some profound philosophical epiphany. Sometimes it's the same logic fallacy referred to in this video: "But we've always treated cats and dogs like they're not meat for eating".

To be clear, I'm not trying to shut anyone down. I think this is a great topic, and I'm just pointing out a counter-argument.

My experience with how people who eat meat tend to draw that line comes from having lived most of my life in or near rural, agricultural areas. So, farmers (chickens, pigs, goats, cows, etc.) and their decisions to raise those animals and how they treated them. But there's also the issue of sentimentality and emotional attachment to individuals - which plays into the cat example and also the decisions to sometimes not eat the animals we know and still eat animals we don't.

When I was younger, we inherited some chickens from a friend and took care of them and ate the eggs. We had no intent to use them for meat, but one died when a horse spooked during a storm and stomped on her. So, here we have a dead chicken - which we'd totally eat if it came from the store...but she had a name and a personality that we knew (and liked, she was a sweet bird), and mom couldn't bear the plucking her let alone cooking and eating her.

Big industry ag - to my understanding - is the source of the farm cruelty we're used to hearing about, because of the economy of scale. Local-scale folks who raise animals for their own use tend to be more aware of the intelligence and suffering of their animals, and are kinder and more practical in how they handle the if, when, and how of slaughtering for meat vs. milk/eggs/other.

I'm a bit disappointed by the way he treated this issue. In order to think philosophically about animals, we need to come up with a theory of animal rights. The theory needs to convincing in order for us to agree animal have rights. A major starting point is acknowledging that ONLY humans recognize rights. Animals don't think about the lives of other animals (or plants) before they eat them (as far as we know). From here, we assume - animals have rights because we, people, think they should have rights.
Why should they have rights, and what kind of rights? Every right needs to be justified individually.
Why do we treat cats and dog differently than other animals? He did not answer that question; but there is an answer to it, of course. Because WE DOMESTICATED them. Simply put, we trained and selectively breeded them generation after generation to respond to our actions and emotions, to the point they are genetically programmed to behave the way we won't us to behave. Wild animals don't do that, because they can't. Pets are different because by centuries of breeding, we made them to be attractive to us. WE made them different.
Our civilization put the entire animal world under our control. Is it right that it's under our control? Consider it philosophically.
Anyway, THINK about it yourself. Don't just take other's words' for it.

There is a rational reason for why we should feel less than keen to eat Fluffy or a dog, but not have that same problem with eating pigs. While pigs are omnivores and will eat meat if it is fed to them (harking back to the days when farmed pigs were fed whatever food waste remained as well as whatever feed they might normally forage up), dogs and cats are carnivores. And while the meat on any limb might be relatively safe to eat, eating their internal organs (the offal, if you will) can be bad for your health. The liver, in wolves, can actually lead to you ingesting a lethal dose of vitamin A (and before you argue that people eat Cod liver - a carnivorous fish - it is a matter of scale, ingest to much cod liver oil and you will reach the same point).

But then, these mostly unconscious biases that we have in what we will and won't eat (meat wise), in a western, historically Abrahamic society mostly come from the cultural following of Leviticus. This is where you'll find the dietary rules that tend to list the things we don't/won't eat because they are 'unclean'. Most of these have a sound (historical) basis for why we shouldn't eat them. "Every animal that does not have a divided hoof or that does not chew the cud is unclean for you" for example would include cats, dogs, and pigs (which are specially singled out, because of the higher chance of diseases moving from pigs to humans AND because in a desert dwelling society - which this was - preserving its meat was nigh on impossible and as such eating pork was more likely to harm then heal).

However, this doesn't mean that in a case of starve or die I wouldn't end up eating the family cat or dog if there was absolutely nothing else left to eat. I'd just be warier about what parts I ate.

Omnivores, by definition, need to eat meat. From health experts I've consulted, the proteins found in other non-meat sources are not plentiful enough or diverse enough to stay healthy. So I don't believe your claim that we can do without.

I don't think you actually discredited the intelligence-based "caste" system. Just because a few primates may be smarter than some humans doesn't topple the entire argument. Intelligence is scalar and most people give preferential/more humane treatment to smarter animals with the notable exception of pigs. The vast majority of people would never eat chimp. And even if a human were so mentally handicapped that they had less cognitive function than a fish, you still would not be justified in eating them, because of the suffering it would cause to those around them-- No meat-eater would see slaughtering someone else's pet as justified either.

The argument for need is also still valid in a broader sense. If experiments need to be done to innovate and improve quality of life than the utilitarian view mandates that we experiment on less-cognitive creatures to prevent human suffering. And even vegans cause non-human suffering just by existing. They take up land that displaces other creatures. They emit CO2. They commit genocide on all of the animal bacteria living in their mouth whenever they brush their teeth. You cannot exist without imposing on other creatures and you cannot make the argument for "minimizing" your impact unless you view suffering, intelligence, and sentience as scalar rather than as a dichotomy.

...actually, this episode made me ponder things, and I realized: I would be OK with eating a cat if it was prepared and served well. Same with a dog or any other creature out there, whether it's a lion, a snake, or a rat. My philosophy on eating animals is "so long as it can be served in an appetizing manner".

Am I for cruelty to animals that are in farms? No, because I believe that such treatment causes the resulting meat to suffer in quality. By improving the lives of those animals, I suspect that the quality of my meals will improve.

Same with eating my cat when she passes on: she's lived a good life, has been well cared for, and the vet says she's healthy every time I take her in. If she continues that way until she passes on, then so long as someone can prepare her in an appetizing manner, I am fine with eating her. I've not see any recipes that serve house cat that sound pleasant, nor have I encountered any restaurants in my area that offer house cat as a menu item, but I'm more then open to trying it if presented the opportunity.




Look, CC Team, I know what you're trying to do: you want to use these next few episodes to provoke us to be introspective and to use the tools you've been teaching us throughout so that we can re-evaluate long-held beliefs and elevate our thinking to a higher plane of reasoning.

But maybe next time, we could try a less politically charged example such as "if we claim to love animals, why do we test our dangerous drugs on them"? Or maybe just stick to that example of the pharmaceutical industry example? Something that helps get the point of "we're hypocritical about how we treat animals" across without turning the forum into an ideological flame war and shutting everyone's mind down to what you're trying to teach about philosophy. I know you guys can do this - you've discussed similarly charged topics in a surprisingly balanced and informative manner before (CC Government, anyone?) So why is it proving so difficult to do here, when the whole concept of Philosophy is supposed to be about balanced discussions and weighing all possibilities?

...or are you planning on topping this series off by asking the "pro-choice vs pro-life" question because you want to see Youtube explode in a fireball of hatred and pitchforks as stay shut up in your homes when real life protest marches walk up and down your streets? Because if you were hoping to engage us on a reasoned discussion of THAT quagmire after these last couple of opening salvos, I'd suggest taking a step back and re-examining whether you want CC to go down the path of the History and Discovery channels and into the toilet (especially after CC Geography's amazing debut: I suspect many others haven't forgotten that series quite yet, either, and I'd hate to think it was the start of a trend instead of the simple misstep I hoped it was).

I disliked this video like the discrimination one, purely because you don't pursue the other side. Philosophy shows that there's multiple sides to any argument, as long as you rationally argue it out. Similarly, if philosophy says you should be consistent, be consistent in your videos. Be consistent in your role as a educator, and justify both sides as an educator. Show both sides and don't press one side of the argument because you believe strongly in it. What if we take this argument one step further? Is it ok to eat plants? Sure we don't connect with them in the same way we do with animals, but they are forms of life. Even if the don't have what we formally consider to be a brain, their "objective" is to stay alive and reproduce just like us or animals. So why draw the line at plants? If you're going to say that something not being like us in some way isn't a justification for mistreating it, what is the arbitrary difference with plants that makes it ok?

Life is life. Things eat things to live (unless you can do photosynthesis.) Are all the carnivores immoral? We don't kill people because it's safer to live in a society where people can trust each other. No such expectation exists between us and other animals.

That said, it's worth dropping in the environmental argument why people should, if not go vegetarian, at least reduce meat consumption: It takes a lot of energy to raise animals. You lose around 90% energy going down the food chain. So you could feed lots more people on less resources if you fed people plants directly instead of feeding animals to then feed to people. Devil's Advocate for a moment here - it is a pretty significant assumption that self-consistence of beliefs is desirable, or even that it is entirely possible. It seems worth exploring the idea that it might be altogether impossible for a system of ethics to be entirely consistent across all experience; in particular it seems to easily break down any time we try to generalize across intuitive (rather than explicit) boundaries. Some variation of Godel's Incompleteness Theorem for logic could be true - that there are things which are true or false within any system of ethical rules that those rules simply cannot prove one way or the other.

SMBC had an interesting thing to say about the idea of self-consistence in one comic, though in that strip it was in regard to political movements; your movement only really survives if it is flexible enough to modify its agenda as people come and go and the world evolves; if it is tied to a self-consistent ideal, it's destined to fail. It might be useful to consider that Ethics functions similarly - if you tie your ethics to a specific set of self-consistent rules, you can never remain ethical long-term; if what you call Ethical is ultimately arbitrary and can change with whatever authority or environment you need it to, you can always be Ethical (even though that term loses most of its implied meaning).

The Naturalist Philosophy of Science, that truth is objective, and discoverable via observation, evidence, and logic, works amazingly well for uncovering the behaviour of the universe around us. Ethics may not be a function of that system; in many ways they seem not to be. It seems unusual to demand that they conform to a system in which they do not arise naturally.

Also, there are strong moral cases for killing animals to protect other animals. Killing Cane Toads, feral cats and other pests is seen as right, since these animals disrupt the natural order of the ecology they were introduced to.

The largest issue with the meat industry is its treatment of the animals within, and the ecological impact it has on the natural world (for example, cows produce tonnes of methane, a greenhouse gas) and I agree the treatment of rabbits by the makeup industry is cruel in that it's a life of pain before death, but I have no issue with things like free range chickens and other more considerate ways of rearing animals for meat and animal products. The obvious response would be that animals can't be held to the same moral standards as humans because they're not the same as humans (implying a lower stature). If that were true, then why must they get "equal consideration of interest", as humans?

As a case study, what would you do if you had a choice between saving 1 human or saving 1 dog (or a lion or a whale or a cockroach) assuming you don't have any acquaintance or connection to either? The perceived morality of the animal, whether human or non, dictates whether we are willing to subjugate it, and to what extent; the only other factor that plays a role are societal mores. In ancient days all animals and humans were ripe for subjugation, but only the morally deficient humans; war captives, children of slaves, criminals, could be subjugated. The same justifications were given during the transatlantic slave trade, and we today use the same justifications to imprison persons convicted of crimes. Society is willing to separate itself from the perceived immoral members of society, and subjugate those humans and non-humans to less preferential treatment than the moral receive, because morality is understood to be conducive to a well-functioning society. This reflects societies' desire to empower the morally upstanding and punish the morally deficient, which is what we understand to be justice. The morally deficient disobey laws (if they are human), they are lazy and good for nothing (if they are cows), so to balance the scales of justice they must be dis-empowered or else society will collapse.

We would see this as a threat and act accordingly, but we shouldn't blame the animal for acting according to it's own natural instincts.

I'd argue that nobody has any rights unless they demand them. Basically, animals have not entered into the social contract we have established with other humans, so they are not entitled to any of the rights we confer onto others within that social contract.

Think about how we treat insane people. These are people that basically have lost the ability to consent to the social contract. So we put them away. Now, unlike animals, we don't kill them or eat them or anything because there's the implicit assumption that insanity may somehow be temporary and at some point in the future they may regain their ability to join the social contract, either naturally or through medical means. The same goes for severely disabled people, although they usually integrate better with society than insane people so we're typically more lenient.

Now what's different with animals is there's absolutely no expectation that they may at some point in the future become capable of consenting to the social contract. So we remove those safeguards that we normally place on impaired humans. One of those safeguards is not being eaten by other humans.

However, it's entirely true that animals do suffer like humans, and that should change our behavior. For example, we shouldn't torture animals. But that's not because they have the right to not be tortured (because they have no rights), but because causing needless suffering is just universally bad. People who do it should be punished not because the animal's rights were violated, but because that's some seriously psychopathic behavior and there's a fair chance the person will start torturing people.

I definitely understand where vegans are coming from, and it definitely sucks for animals because we are causing them harm, but (unfortunately) there is no universal right to not be harmed. You win the right to not be harmed (conditionally), by participating in the social contract. And the "conditionally" part is the important part, it defines the rules of the contract. But animals can't communicate with us and tell us that they understand and accept those conditions, so they cannot agree to them. But who knows, maybe in the future we'll learn how to communicate with animals better so that they can, in that event I'm totally for animal emancipation. By the way this argument is the same for all beings, not just animals (for example, artificially intelligent beings).

Here's my philosophy - domesticated animals were bred for specific purposes by human beings - chickens to grow rich meat, horses for travel, dogs for hunting. As we are the direct breeders of these species, we are given the same rights to do with these animals as Mother Nature is to do with all natural species. That means that because we are the "creator" of these animals, we are free to do with them as seen fit. Think of it as an artist doing as they please with a work of theirs. They can hang it in a gallery, mass-produce it, burn it, sell it, or even cut it up and reuse it in another work - that last one being emblematic of gene sharing, i.e. with spider-silk-producing goats. This works in reverse for animals that we have no jurisdiction of their purpose - we are morally right to be upset about a scientifically important lion getting killed for sport or elephants being mistreated by the circus industry. However, I've yet to discern a "speed limit" per say to how cruel a human can be to a domestic species, like obviously raping a chicken is NOT okay.

Personally, and I think this might be the next episode, I think that our moral stance on using animals depends on our emotional connection to them. Fluffy was a pet and has spent his whole life in the same home, so we're sure to have an emotional connection. Some cow from some farm that lands on my plate could barely be less emotionally connected to me than it already is.

Thing is, if I need to kill a human who I don't know and should have no emotional connection to, then I probably won't kill it. We probably have some sort of minimum emotional connection to other humans simply because of the fact that we're both humans. There have been examples of humans killing other humans because of their needs though. At some point, the need surpasses the emotional connection. In a utilitarian way you could say that the hurt of me not killing the human is greater than the hurt of the human + the hurt of knowing what the human feels due to the emotional connection.

In animals we can be less sure of how it feels because we are not the same species. To take this a step further: We know even less about how plants feel, hence why we barely think about how they feel. For example this video, it only talks about animals, yet it has been proven that plants also react to negative stimuli like being eaten. We have less of a base emotional connection to plants compared to animals and less to animals as we have to humans.

To summarize: We have an emotional connection to other beings. The strength of this emotional connection depends on how similar it is to humans. The less human it is, the less empathy we have for it. So whether we will treat something like a human will be the sum of the hurt of the action and our view of the feeling of hurt for that being. The closer it is to human hurting, the larger feeling of hurt and the larger the threshold for intentional suffering.

This video makes an unexamined assumption that all animals are equally capable of suffering. We shouldn't assume that the suffering of all animals is just what it would be for us if we were in the place of those animals.

What does a chicken actually think and feel when we lock it in a cage or trim its beak? Is it capable of understanding the situation? There's no doubt that it can react to pain, but it's less clear that it has the mental capacity to actually suffer. In order to fairly judge the moral value of what we do to chickens, we really need an understanding of the inner life of chickens.

Apes obviously should be protected since they are close enough to us that they almost certainly think and feel much like we do. Pigs also seem to have a morally relevant inner life, so maybe they do. Crows are quite social and seem to mourn the dead, so perhaps they actually do mourn the dead, and in that case we certainly shouldn't kill them. In contrast, chickens seem to be biological machines that just eat and lay eggs.

"I don't care" can be a philosophically deep sentiment. I'm not sure why this was a video in particular... its a pretty single-sided view of the issue and a one-dimensional view at that. Humans treat non-sentient life the way they do out of economic convenience, demand, and need. Sure there are other potential avenues for research, work, and food now but at one time there wasn't as much... and arguably in some cases that need is still rather strong. But supposing alternatives can be found humans are still going to be displacing, harming, and killing non-sentient life. Vegans do too. Their very existence in a modern civilization is an affront to nature and it is currently unavoidable (even in the most ideal green imagining of modern society)... humans have through the use of intelligence and technology far overstepped what would be otherwise humanity's lot. There was a constant mentioning of forced servitude, truly a terrible wrong and evil, and I would argue never truly a necessity but it existed and only stopped existing when humans developed the means to have superior alternatives such as machinery or because it was untenable like the constant fear of revolts with actual revolts which in some cases were successful (like the Haitian Revolution). It may be comforting to see the abolition of slavery as an ethical victory but mostly it was socioeconomic factors that brought it to an end. Is it any surprise that the more industrial/developed northern union States was anti-slavery while the confederate States that were far less industrial/developed were pro-slavery? Which is what I think will be the end of meat-eating... better synthetic meats that will likely cost lest, be easier to produce, and be higher in quality. The same thing is true about the terrible situation of pollution where humanity is literally killing itself and the world they inhabit... alternatives exist but they are not of the same quality or cost-efficiency so it isn't going to change much. Sure you could try to live a 'green lifestyle' and be an environmental/climate advocate but that isn't going to change the ultimate trend. Technology however will.

So if someone feels uncomfortable or that it is against their conscience to eat meat, I can fully understand and support them in that. However if they think they are doing anything significant or that they are being noble while their very existence is the destruction of other non-human and human life as well as the planet... or that their efforts are somehow similar to past efforts... I think that is really absurd. I have no doubt someday humanity will not do to animals what is currently done in factory farming... but in the same way we may view George Washington who owned slaves (who in his will liberated them and gave them part of his estate) will likely be the way we see those of us today. A regretful arrangement caused by many different factors that we grew out of. Ethics evolves and is if you like it or not is largely situational and an afterthought of whatever the current arrangement is. If it wasn't humanity would of never developed and likely would of died out due to environmental and climate changes that were world-wide or regional.

Progress is progressive and accumulative. Someday I also think the existence of a labor class as currently constituted will be seen as unethical (likely again due to technology) and akin to a modern-slavery. So do you stop going to stores? Do you turn off the power and the internet? Or do you fight for a better today for that labor class and work for the hope to someday move past it? But if someone wanted to stop depending on human labor that is so poorly treated I could fully understand why. I choose the latter and the same for animals... better conditions for them today and try to reduce factory farming while working for a day where such things will no longer be. In the last philosophy video about discrimination, you more or less said that if you spend enough time around someone you consider different from you, then you'll eventually come to understand that there are more similarities between you than there are differences. But the dividing line of species just happens to be the one where we start to see way more differences than similarities.

If neanderthals were still around, this would be a completely different story. I could almost guarantee you that in that parallel world, this video would instead be titled something like "Non-Human, Non-Neanderthal Animals" or something like that. The reality is that in the world we live in, even the most similar living species to humans still can't communicate with humans using the same languages we use. There are no other species that subscribe to any of the moral frameworks that we subscribe to. Even if we decide that all animals should be treated without pain, no other species is even capable of agreeing with us. Lions won't care what we think is wrong; they'll keep killing gazelles anyway. Perhaps the one contractarian principle that holds true throughout the entire planet is that, with the exception of symbiosis, organisms simply don't care about those that do not belong to their own species. A bear has personhood in a bear community, whereas a frog has none. Why shouldn't we follow every other species' example? Why should we burden ourselves with the task of giving personhood to those who would never return the favour?



Of course, the same could be said about two humans who happen to be extremely different, only sharing a common genome and little else. Or of course, one could argue that my assumptions about the differences outweighing the similarities was simply wrong, that by focusing even deeper on the common details, one could perceive a unity that extends past our idea of "species", beyond our individual definitions of "life". Of course there are going to be a billion different perspectives on the issue, just like everything in philosophy. It all comes down to arbitrary boundaries. It's arbitrary because there are no standard measurements, only intuitions and vague notions. It's arbitrary because it's different to everyone. There are endless reasons behind every belief, endless levels of validity, but invalid ideas can exist just as well as valid ideas can. One specimen has personhood in one human's view and has none in another's view, while other humans might assign it varying degrees of personhood in between both extremes, and that's simply the way it is, without anyone having to be proven right or wrong over another. It's possible to live in a world where others hold beliefs we do not support, and we must simply tolerate them without intervening. Or maybe we do have a responsibility to intervene where we believe there is a position that should not be held.

Personally, I find it fascinating and beautiful that these dilemmas exist and perhaps can never be solved. I don't want us all to have to agree, and I don't want anyone's views to have to be silenced just because someone else thinks another view is more valid. But at the same time, I appreciate and endorse rationality just as much as the next guy. I'm constantly torn between the aesthetic appeal of epistemic diversity and the intellectual appeal of moral uniformity. It's a wonderful sort of chaos that we all have these unsettled disputes that rage over generations while society simply continues anyway as if the lack of an answer is necessary to our survival. Philosophers strive for consistency, but maybe consistency is ultimately impossible. Perhaps hypocrisy is inevitable. And maybe it's not as bad as we might think. Or maybe it's exactly as bad as we think. What would even be the difference?

...This always seems to happen when I think about philosophical questions too hard. Every time, I just get carried away into the absolute, where I conclude that "perspectives may sustainably differ" for subjectivity's sake and leave it at that. I personally don't find the topic to be of dire urgency; I like engaging with it because I find it fun. But there are others who do find it a matter of life and death, and that intellectual dissonance is fascinating to me. It's that paradoxical fuel for argument that I can't take my eyes off of long enough to actually get anywhere with the argument itself.

There is an another argument for eating some animals but not others: the evolutionary argument. This runs that certain species have evolved to eat other species and so their survival instinct has evolved to make them incapable of feeling empathy for their food. For example, wolves don't feel empathy for deer or rabbits but they have been known to adopt orphaned coyotes. They feel empathy for the baby coyote because they are do not perceive coyotes as food.

By the same token, humans are not capable of feeling empathy with fish. Even when we keep them as pets, it's usually more for the aesthetic beauty of the fish tank with it's many coloured tropical fish then for a sense of nurturing for the fish. When one of the fish dies, we flush it without feeling the slightest bit of sorrow and even make a silly joke or two. When was the last time you heard some say, "ooh, what a cute little clam, " or saw an animal rights activist hoisting a sign that read, "save the cod." Because fish are an important part of our natural diet, and we simply do not feel empathy for our food. I would say that fish and seafood are the only animals humans should be eating because it's the only animal we as a species are incapable of feeling empathy for and therefore the only animals that is a natural part of our evolutionary diet.

When you eat almost any fresh fruit you are basically eating it alive, since fruit is known to have metabolism, including synthesis of new components (starch to simple sugars is the most prominent) and a rudimentary immune sistem. If you go by this logic, then you would be limited to eating things that are not alive at all, such as animal by-products like non-fertilized eggs and milk, or grains and seeds. You could argue that eating fruits is also OK since fruits evolved to be eaten in order to spread the plants seeds... but if you are not spreading the seeds or if you are destroying them by cooking the fruit, then this is meaningless as well. On the other hand, eating grains and other seeds would imply hindering the plants reproduction by destroying their progeny... so isn't that kinda mean as well? In the end, I think we have to accept that it is almost impossible to survive without harming another living being in some fashion, but that is the sad truth of being a living being that needs to obtain its nutrients from other living beings. It would be nice if we could survive only out of inorganic substances, like plants or bacteria do, but we can't... yet. Hopefuly, science will advance one day so much that we can just synthesize our food without ever needing to harm or kill another living being ever again, but unless you want to starve yourself to death in order not to harm anything... then there is no solution to this issue right now.

I'd argue that if it's not wrong for a lion to eat a gazelle or a grizzly bear to eat a fish, it's equally not wrong for a human to eat a chicken or cow. However, there is a big difference between bears eating fish/ lions eating gazelles and humans eating chickens and cows; bears and lions don't keep their prey in tiny cages nor maim them to keep them from hurting each other, nor pump them full of artificial growth hormones and antibiotics. And on fish farms, people feed the fish cheap crud that they'd never eat in their natural environment, not to mention they're kept in a tank and can't swim around getting the toning and exercise fish normally would in their natural environment (keep in mind salmon swim upstream, against the current, even UP waterfalls)- that inactivity actually negatively affects their taste; bears and lions don't do that with their prey either. What humans do to their prey is wrong because it's robbing them of their natural order/agency in addition to their lives. We give them incredibly shitty lives and then kill them. At least gazelles and fish get to roam around in their natural habitat eating their natural diet before they get eaten. The "necessary to survive" argument doesn't apply there, we can easily keep livestock without doing all those horrible things to them, we just do them because it's more convenient and less costly- but as Hank pointed out, the same was true of slavery, and it wasn't right then either. Free range chickens and the like help, but the public tends to ridicule those options as hippie nonsense and "unnecessarily expensive".
As for the animal testing argument, using them for something important like medical testing is one thing, using them for something completely optional like cosmetics is another story. We can live without makeup, we need medicine. And in the case of Cecil the lion, did that hunter kill Cecil for food or self-defense, a necessity for survival? Or did he just kill Cecil for Sport, killed for no reason other than liking to kill things? Hunting for sport is a lot less philosophically defensible.
As for why not eat your pets upon their death... well... depending on how they died, they may not be safe to consume, and I imagine many of them would not taste very good assuming they even have much meat to begin with. I think the objection is based on personal connection, people tend to consider pets as part of the family. Some people have domestic pet chickens, not livestock. I imagine they wouldn't want to eat their pet chicken even if they aren't a vegetarian. There was even an episode of Simpsons where Homer got a lobster that he originally intended to eat, but then decided he liked it too much as a pet and backed out, only to eventually accidentally boil to death anyway when trying to give it a hot bath. He was sad about losing his pet, but he tearfully ate it anyway, saying that's what it would have wanted. If you claim pets are part of the family, then it's only fair to apply the same rule for to them as for humans: bury them upon their death so they can act as fertilizer for plants- which can then in turn be eaten. Livestock aren't pets, there's no personal connection with them, they are just part of the predator and prey equation of natural order- which is absent from a pet relationship. However, that then raises the question of cannibalism. Why shouldn't one eat other people they don't have personal connections with? For the same reason most predators don't generally eat their own species?

Martin Heidegger talks about a phenomenon knows as "distancing" in Being and Time. One can not consider something, ethically or otherwise, when it is phenomenologically (not necessarily physically) "distanced" from ones mind. Basically, if you like sausages, don't learn about how they are made. I eat meat because I am able to psychologically distance myself from the moral considerations of doing so. In an increasingly globalized works it is becoming more and more necessary to be able to distance ourselves from the moral implications of our choices. I need to be able to buy clothes without thinking about sweat shops, and buy chocolate for my girlfriend without considering working in fields all day picking beans. How could I live in America and do anything, without feeling morally guilty?This relates to the "trolley problem" in which changing the circumstances of the thought experiment make it harder to phycologically distance the moral implications of the decision. This idea may suggest that there is no such thing as morality or ethics. Ethics is simply a pragmatic fiction that is developed to cover up something that is purely psychological. It is possible to distance ones mind from moral decisions too much. Hannah Arendt talks about "functionalism" in the Banality of Evil. A nazi officer can treat shipping people like shipping crates of chom choms. If he doesn't take the time to psychologically consider what he is doing, he can distance himself from the ethical considerations of it. Is this what makes cyber bullying so easy?Too much consideration of ethical issues in decision making can make it impossible to function. On the other hand, not enough consideration can lead to awful things. It is important to have a gadfly that provokes us to consider these issues, even though they annoy us and make us feel uncomfortable. Thank you Hank Green, for being a gadfly. I'll submit a view of Utilitarian Speciesist.
The sustenance, improvement, and expansion of humanity is the primary moral good.
Minimizing suffering is a secondary moral good.

The utility of a creature to humanity determines its moral value.
The utility of eating meat and veg is higher than that of veg alone in terms of energy density per unit volume or mass, therefore it is morally acceptable to eat meat, even if it is not necessary.
This creates a hierarchy of suitable animal food sources, with things with low ancillary value and high breeding rates, such as chickens, fish, and arguably rodents and insects, being the primary food sources. Cows and pigs (and similar animals.. deer sheep, etc) are next, as they require more resources to grow, but a single individual goes a lot further. IE Beef takes 10x the resources than poultry, but they also provide more ancillary resources, such as bonemeal, leather and other fabrics, and numerous chemical or physical ingredients in use in other parts of our life and society.

This goes on and on in a somewhat fuzzy way. IE Its more acceptable to eat a deer than a lion, but more acceptable to eat a lion than a human.

Other humans are the least morally acceptable meat source. IE you must have no other option but to die, and you must minimize suffering if you choose to eat another person.
This is still discouraged, as we know eating our own kind can have many ill effects that outweigh simple caloric intake, but its arguably better than death. The exact weighting of survival vs cannibalism is left to the individual.

The typical utility of a cat or dog to most humans is that of emotional support and pest control. Both of which are of greater value than the energy density of the meat they would provide. Emotional support allows us to function at a better level, and pest control helps keep us free from disease, and our food supplies safe.

The utility of a lion, on the other hand, is somewhere between pleasure from viewing, and not at all useful to humans. It is made of meat, but has limited secondary resource potential, and does not breed at a high enough rate to be effectively farmed. So to kill one is morally wrong, as it increases suffering, unless said lion is threatening the sustained life of a human or group of humans.

Eh, this episode about animal rights seems to have glossed over Carl Cohen's arguments while promoting Peter Singer's arguments. Here's the problem with that: first, Peter Singer is a utilitarian. Pure utilitarianism is lazy, bad ethics when compared to deontology or virtue ethics. Second, as Carl Cohen's essay points out, Peter Singer's utilitarian argument could be easily re-purposed to argue that the pleasure people (read humans) experience from eating meat outweighs the animal's pain because humans can experience higher/better pleasures than animals (see J.S. Mill). Third, Carl Cohen's arguments are much stronger than Singer, because Cohen correctly points out, "A right, properly understood, is a claim, or potential claim, that one party may exercise against another. The target against whom such a claim may be registered can be a single person, a group, a community, or (perhaps) all humankind...Animals (that is, nonhuman animals, the ordinary sense of that word) lack this capacity for free moral judgment. They are not beings of a kind capable of exercising or responding to moral claims. Animals therefore have no rights, and they can have none".

This is not to say that the current system of food production is good. That system is inefficient, unnecessarily cruel, and reflects poorly on the society that allows it to continue to exist as it does. But, animals that are not capable of responding to moral claims do not have rights, so it seems that eating animals is morally acceptable. Animals may, in certain societies, have privileges that people bestow upon them, but under no circumstances do they have rights.

A better argument for moral considerations regarding non-human animals would be to argue that the current system of food production reflects poorly on our character as persons, states, organizations, etc. So, in order to reform our character, we should change how we treat animals, although I would still argue that eating meat is perfectly acceptable, especially when that meat is prepared/brought to market in a way that minimizes the suffering that the animals experience.

Link to Cohen's essay: http://spot.colorado.edu/~heathwoo/phil1200,Spr07/cohen.pdf

I like to justify my actions by distinguishing a category of animals, pets. Pets gives companionship to those who own them and if loved, they will return the affection, sometimes in a way not so easily understood by humans such as cat catching a rat and offering it to you first. These pets that are well fed and loved learns to look outside the scope of simple survival and reproduction. I think that is what really makes these pets special. This difference can extend to their effect to their owner(s). Pets, unlike livestocks and wild animals, like I said, provide comfort and even love if treated well. Just like how humans become different people by how they're treated, animals do too. By my logic, I really have nothing against killing really any non-pet animals for food or other purpose unless doing so causes major change in ecosystem or impairs some genetic research. This includes dogs and cats, as long as they're farmed, not grown as a pet.

I never saw the one point I was most interested in seeing when judging my justification for eating animals - they kill and eat each other all the time. I don't approve of causing animals unnecessary pain, but I feel justified eating animals, especially plentiful herbivores, because most of them will be killed and eaten at some point in their life anyway. The house kitty has a much smaller chance of being killed by another animal.

The way I see it, it is about uniqueness.

If I kill some random dog or rabbit or bear, the uniqueness of the world does not decrease. (One rabbit is more or less the same as any other rabbit). however as you increase in intelligence (and specifically the ability to use abstract reasoning) you being to accumulate unique ideas, thoughts, and memories. killing a human is generally bad because it removes unique information. (I see nothing morally wrong about murdering someone, if you have a way to preserve their mind for potential retrieval later).

I would not feel uncomfortable eating a dog or a cat in general. I would feel uncomfortable eating my dog or a friends dog however. but that is not due to it being immoral so much as the fact that it will reflect poorly on me and make achieving my goals harder (nobody wants to work with the guy who ate their dog) thus it is generally a non-optimal behavior, and as such should be avoided. and I would feel bad eating a pig or a chicken if for the same reason if someone I knew was emotionally attached to them, this is not an internal inconsistency. (Eating dogs is not wrong; hurting your friends feelings is).

Enslaving humans was wrong, because humans are unique. and society would be objectively worse without the contributions members of previously enslaved races have made. (for instance, we would not have Neil Degrasse Tyson advocating for science and thus drawing more people into the field, increasing humanities overall scientific advancement). society is unlikely to see major benefits from freed chickens, thus freeing chickens is not a moral obligation.

If it is proven that a non-human species is intelligent enough that individuals can actually make contributions to society and have ideas that are new, unique, and meaningful. then I would fervently support the halting of any activities that could harm them. but animals don't, and thus I don't.

Fact: Vitamin B-12, a vitamin we need to live, has to come from other animals. Even the supplements come from animal sources. Humans must eat meat or cheese. Vegans who abstain from animal products will have this deficiency, and have to take a B-12 supplement, which always comes from a animal byproduct. Humans need to eat other animals, just like cats must consume meat or go blind. So eating meat or consuming another animal is necessary for survival. The best way to explain this is through contractarianism. Our ancestors needed to eat and they didn't have the option of being vegetarians, so it was socially acceptable to eat meat. Then we evolved and became good hunters, and the surplus of food allowed us to keep certain animals as pets (we went a step up on Maslow's pyramid of needs). The same surplus of food that allowed us to keep pets meant that we didn't need to eat them after they died (just like they didn't eat dead people), so it became socially unacceptable to eat them.
This also accounts for cultural differences. In some parts of the world people did need to consume their pets in times of need (China, for ex), so with time it became socially acceptable to do so, even without the need.
Since we can lead healthy, happy, and fulfilling lives without harming those who share this world with us, why on earth wouldn't we?
Speciesism (by that defenition) should be called humanism.

The way I look at it, it basically comes down to negative rights. Most of us recognise that there are certain negative human rights and that violating these rights is immoral, for example forcing someone to do something, killing someone or depriving someone of their freedom unless they commit a crime against these morals themselves first and initiate the violence.

If we are to extend these rights, like a right to life, to animals, we would also have to hold animals accountable for violating these rights. If a lion has a right to life then it also violates the same right of the gazelle it kills. Is it reasonable to hold the lion accountable for its crimes, or would other lions ever hold it accountable? It's not about intelligence or anything else, it's just the fact that we are different from every other animal in several ways, and the idea of morality is one of them.

Obviously animal cruelty is not ok, both because you impose sadistic or unnecessary suffering on something that might not have a sense of right and wrong but is living and conscious nonetheless, and because in the case of pets, humans who has a concept of rights form a strong emotional bond to these animals and by hurting the animals you're hurting those people.
