Generally, I find the pragmatic answer is the one I'll go with. If the alternatives to eating animals are difficult or impractical compared to the supposed moral gain, then eating animals with little other practical or emotional value is fine.

One could also note that similar arguments could have been made for slavery in their time, since during the times when slavery was prevalent there wasn't really an alternative. Only lords and the wealthy owned land and a single owner could hardly be capable of working all the land they owned, and in many cases many lower class people could sign up willingly to become indentured servants since the alternative was starving on the streets; such is the case with ancient Rome, who made "consensual slavery" a path to citizenship. Nowadays slavery is impractical in most of the world, as the industrial revolution made the process exponentially easier, which is how Britton outlawed slavery without needing a war over it.

The reason we still use animals for meat is that largely speaking; its still difficult and impractical to find other methods of consuming large amounts of nutrients and calories, especially protein. Since Protein can only really be found in large quantities in meat, and we need it to retain our brain and muscle structures. So far the only alternatives to animal meat are something like Tofu, which you have to consume a ridiculous amount of to get your recommended intake of tofu, and "synthetic meat" which is currently still only in the "proof of concept" stage and requires a ridiculous amount of money to produce.

A side note: on the utilitarian side of things, there are some animals we can eat that do not have much if any capacity to suffer, such as the case of fish, who are incapable of feeling pain. However, pragmatically speaking, we're slowly ruining this source of meat in several ways, such as over fishing natural populations and focusing too much on fish that is popular for its taste to the exclusion of other perfectly edible ones. Its much more practical to utilize fisheries, especially if its an indoor fishery, since you can pack a lot of fish into a small area, and produce relatively large amounts of meat; which unlike "wild fish" is unlikely to have as many contaminants that can lead to illness, such as mercury poisoning. As ironic as that is.

Screw it, I'll throw in my two cents:

a) No, it is not okay to make animals suffer without cause.
b) The argument of necessity is the only argument because the way our bodies work now, it is impossible to sustain oneself without destroying life. One may make the argument that animals can think and feel whereas a plant may not, but from a purely moral stance, it is still depriving a living creature of the one thing it "wants," which is to continue to live. In my mind, it's all the same.
c) Being speciesist is a part of natural selection, as is prioritizing other animals (such as pets) over others based on their usefulness to a human. Befriending humans (even indirectly your enemies) by making unspoken contracts to have some respect for their bodies can be good for the species as a whole. Similarly, a pet, by serving a human and making their lives better, can earn a similar contract. Why would we eat the dog when he can do other things for us? Additionally, a dog that catches a lifetime of food or entertains a human for its lifetime has earned the respect for its corpse.
d) Livestock is livestock. They are domesticated animals, bred with the specific purpose of dying and becoming something else. Given that point of view, I would think that having a painless, calm life, being well-fed, being allowed to continue your bloodline until the day of your death would be as much as any farm animal could expect. I feel that I could empathize with that situation and be content, given that typically there would be no other life for a cow or chicken. Farms don't give their livestock this treatment, but if they did, they wouldn't be depriving that bit of livestock of anything it would do outside of the farm in nature. Eat, have sex and be content.

Humans and animals are different. Here are the stages of life: Rocks are not alive. Plants are alive but have no soul, they just live and grow. Animals are alive and have souls. They have personalities, wants and needs they know about and try their best to fulfil, and also have a level of intelligence. Humans are alive, have souls, and have spirits - the ability to contemplate the why of life. So what separates man from beast? The ability to question existence, belief or disbelief in a higher power, morals, the purpose of life and death, basically the concept of philosophy itself is what makes us, us.

The reason we don't eat cats, or dogs, or any animal we have grown attach to isn't because we're speciesist, but rather because as you said our (western/european) culture does not see eating a person as a sign of respect, but one of disrespect. We don't eat fluffy not because cats are more deserving of respect than other animals, but because fluffy is not deserving of our disrespect. Any old cat is just the same as eating bugs, or a strange new recipe for pumpkin, but eating our cat is akin to eating family/friends, minus the hygiene issue of cannibalism.
Now whether or not we should try and change ourselves to see eating or reusing our loved ones as a sign of respect, or at least not of sign of disrespect is a different question.

It's about evolution. We have shaped animals to fit our needs, and therefore their behaviour and abilities, and our relationships with them, conform to that. Even as we change animals through domestication, so too has it changed us. We are repulsed by eating dogs because we see them as members of our group, our pack, in the same way they feel about us. Same goes for cats. We do not feel this way about cows, however. They are cattle, not family, and treating them as family therefore seems absurd. Instead, we treat them as evolution has dictated - a domestic source of meat that provides milk and doesn't even fight when we slaughter it.

Much of this is rooted in tradition that is tens of thousands of years old. We can ask the question of how it ended up this way, but most likely it was just a product of evolution, nothing more, and the longer it goes on, the more ingrained it becomes, and the more justified it gets as evolution reinforces it.

This is also why I wax repulsed about the treatment of rabbits for cosmetics. Rabbits have not been bred for this. They have been bred as pets for the children, but cattle for the adults. (This strange divide often causes arguments) The good news is I don't use a lot of cosmetics, so I can have a clean conscience there.

i guess that this question has always been difficult because i think this is a matter of degrees but defining how is hard. I grew up in a rural area and it was clear to me that plants were less unlike animals and us than they seem.

I mean, yeah, fundamentally different, completely different sides of the biological family tree and all, but still, they reacted to stimuli, got sick and died, seemed to feel pain in some limited respect, responded to human voice and tending (the plants we talked to always seemed to grow better and heal better than those we didn't) etc.

I think the thing I'm uncomfortable with here is bright lines. up to and including humans. we should treat the mentally challenged well because it could have been us, but someone unable to fully consider possibilities for themselves can't be expected to navigate society in full freedom or allowed to vote, etc. We should treat Dolphins and apes and the like well because we know they have a similar level of intelligence.

When you get even down into the level of dogs and pigs, though, you start to shade out a bit more. they are very like us, and very unlike us. i'm not opposed to the eating of dogs (though I would be hard pressed to eat any of the dogs I've known once they died). I'd also be hard pressed to do what my more traditionally farm-bred friends would do and raise a cow from infancy then butcher and eat it. but that is sentiment. in our culture in america you don't eat those things/people you care for.

as you continue down the chain though fish and insects to fungi and plants, you have to treat it all with respect and dignity, make sure you're not cruel or inhumane or any of that. but i am justified in fealing more sympathy for a dog than a butterfly than a mushroom than a sunflower than a bacteria.

and just because, as my ethics professor once suggested in class, I wouldn't and shouldn't butcher Bessie the prize winning cow alive with a chainsaw doesn't mean I wouldn't, or shouldn't butcher her at all.
